{{Infobox person | name = Gilbert Rozon | image = Gilbert Rozon 2010.jpg | alt = | caption = Rozon in 2010 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1954|10|26}} | birth_place = [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Canada | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|Month DD, YYYY|Month DD, YYYY}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = [[Canadians|Canadian]] | other_names = | known_for = Founder of ''[[Just for Laughs]]'' | occupation = | spouse = Danielle Roy | children = Charles, Arthur, Édouard }} '''Gilbert Rozon''' (born October 26, 1954) is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[impresario]] and founder of the ''[[Just for Laughs]]'' ({{lang-fr|Juste pour Rire}}) [[comedy festival]], which he created on July 14, 1983. He is also responsible for the development and international deployment of the Just for Laughs/Juste pour Rire brand in over 150 countries. The Just for Laughs festival is considered the largest comedy festival in the world.<ref name="FICC">{{cite web |url=http://www.ficc.qc.ca/fr/Portefeuille/Portefeuille.php |title=Gestion Juste pour Rire Inc. |date=2000–2012 |work=Notre Portefeuille |publisher=Fonds d'investissement de la culture et des communications |language=French |accessdate=12 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120617232311/http://www.ficc.qc.ca/fr/Portefeuille/Portefeuille.php |archivedate=17 June 2012 |df= }}</ref>
==Early life and education== Gilbert Rozon is the eldest of seven children. Raised in [[Saint-André-d'Argenteuil, Quebec|Saint-André d'Argenteuil]], he began working at a young age as a [[paperboy (newspaper delivery)|paperboy]]. At the age of 14 he became a [[gravedigger]], salesman, printer, show organizer, publisher of telephone directories business, key to real estate, etc. It is in this context from his work experience that he developed his sense of humour. After a short stay in [[France]] at age 20, he studied law at the [[Université de Montréal]] where he graduated.<ref name="JdeM">{{cite web|url=http://fr.canoe.ca/divertissement/arts-scene/entrevues/2007/01/07/3215272-jdm.html|title=GILBERT ROZON: Un homme de famille|last=Gaudet|first=Agnès|date=2007-07-01|publisher=[[Le Journal de Montréal]]|language=French|accessdate=12 June 2012}}</ref>
==Career== In 1980, he founded the ''La Grande Virée'' ({{lang-en|The Grand Excursion}}) festival in [[Lachute]] which welcomed more than 60,000 spectators in its first year and more than 80,000 in 1981. For its third year, Gilbert Rozon moved ''La Grande Virée'' to the [[Pointe-aux-Trembles]] neighbourhood in [[Montreal]]. It was a failure.<ref name="MSN">{{cite web|url=http://divertissement.ca.msn.com/musique/festivals/galeries.aspx?cp-documentid=28666128&page=1|title=L’échec du Festival la Grande Virée est à l’origine du Festival Juste pour rire|date=2011-05-09|work=Divertissement|publisher=[[MSN]].ca|language=French|accessdate=12 June 2012}}</ref>
Despite the failure of his first festival in Montreal, Rozon borrowed more than [[Canadian dollar|C$]]1 million to found the ''[[Just for Laughs]]'' festival in 1983. The festival was based in Montreal, although spread to [[Toronto]], [[Chicago]], [[Nantes]] and [[Paris]].<ref name="JdeM2">{{cite web|url=http://fr.canoe.ca/divertissement/arts-scene/nouvelles/2007/05/11/4173677-jdm.html|title=LALIBERTÉ ET ROZON: Du rêve à la réalité|last=Parent|first=Marie-Joëlle|date=2007-07-01|publisher=[[Le Journal de Montréal]]|language=French|accessdate=12 June 2012}}</ref>
Rozon was the [[impresario]] of [[Charles Trenet]] until his death. He was the producer of shows featuring [[Laurent Ruquier]], [[Franck Dubosc]], [[Dieudonné M'bala M'bala]], [[Florence Foresti]], [[Arturo Brachetti]], [[Stéphane Rousseau]], [[Jean-Marc Parent]], [[Jean-Luc Lemoine]], [[Rachid Badouri]], [[André Sauvé]], [[Christophe Alévêque]], etc.
Just for Laughs represents over 75 artists, over 200 hours of television broadcast in over 150 countries each year and hundreds of shows a year. For 25 years, Gilbert Rozon has been at the helm of the festival before giving way to [[Alain Cousineau]] with whom he founded the festival in 1983. He remains chairman and CEO of the group.
Starting in 2006, he became a member of the jury on the [[France|French]] program, ''[[La France a un incroyable talent]]''.<ref name="JdeM3">{{cite web|url=http://fr.canoe.ca/divertissement/tele-medias/nouvelles/2007/09/24/4521877-jdm.html|title=INCROYABLE TALENT: Un deuxième mandat confié à Gilbert Rozon|last=Gaudet|first=Agnès|date=2007-09-24|publisher=[[Le Journal de Montréal]]|language=French|accessdate=12 June 2012}}</ref><ref name="M6">{{cite web|url=http://www.m6.fr/emission-la_france_a_un_incroyable_talent/|title=La France a un incroyable talent|publisher=[[M6 (TV channel)|M6]]|language=French|accessdate=12 June 2012}}</ref>
==Controversy== {{See also|Weinstein effect}} In 1998, Gilbert Rozon received an unconditional discharge from the Quebec Superior Court after pleading and being found guilty of a sexual assault on a 19-year-old woman,<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.radio-canada.ca/nouvelles/23/23224.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120816004608/http://www.radio-canada.ca/nouvelles/23/23224.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-08-16 |title=La victime de Gilbert Rozon contre-attaque |work= |author=Radio-Canada |date=1999-03-08|language=French |accessdate=2012-07-01}}</ref> because a criminal record would have made it difficult for him to travel internationally for his work.<ref name="cbc2000">{{Cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/story/1999/03/13/sexassault990313.html |title=Montreal impresario avoids jail time for sex assault |work= |author=CBC |date=2000-11-10|accessdate=2012-07-01}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.radio-canada.ca/nouvelles/23/23004.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130628053645/http://www.radio-canada.ca/nouvelles/23/23004.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-06-28 |title=Gilbert Rozon pourra voyager librement |work= |author=Radio-Canada |date=1999-03-03|language=French |accessdate=2012-07-01}}</ref> He was also accused of unlawful confinement of a 31-year-old woman but the charge was withdrawn by the police for lack of evidence. Groups of women expressed anger over sentencing they considered as being too lenient.<ref name="cbc2000"/>
On October 18, 2017, Rozon announced he was resigning from his position as the President of Just for Laughs as well as the vice-president of the Montreal Metropolitan Board of Trade, amid allegations of sexual misconduct.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2017/10/18/glibert-rozon-steps-down-just-for-laughs-allegations_a_23248298/|title=Head Of Just For Laughs Festival Resigns Amid Sex Assault Claims|date=18 October 2017|website=Huffingtonpost.ca|accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref>

{{Use Indian English|date=January 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox television channel |name= Hungama TV |logofile = Hungama TV logo.png |logosize = 220px | launch = {{start date and age|26 September 2004}} |network =[[Disney Channels Worldwide]]| owner = [[Disney India Media Networks]] | picture format = [[576i]] ([[SDTV]]) | slogan = ''Machaya Kya?'' | country = [[India]] | language = {{ubl|Hindi|Tamil|Telugu }} | broadcast area = India
Bangladesh | headquarters =[[Mumbai]], Maharashtra, India | sister names = {{plainlist| *[[Bindass]] *[[Disney Channel India|Disney Channel]] *[[Disney International HD]] *[[Disney Junior India|Disney Junior]] *[[Disney XD India|Disney XD]] *[[UTV Movies]] *[[UTV Action]] }} | web = {{url|www.hungamatv.com}} | sat serv 1 = [[Dish TV]] | sat chan 1 = Channel 981 | cable serv 1 = [[DEN Networks]] | cable chan 1 = Channel 432 | sat serv 2 = [[Airtel Digital TV]] | sat chan 2 = Channel 453 | sat serv 3 = [[Tata Sky]] | sat chan 3 = Channel 655 | sat serv 4 = [[Videocon d2h]] | sat chan 4 = Channel 503 | sat serv 5 =[[Sun Direct]] | sat chan 5 = Channel 532 | sat serv 6 =[[Reliance Digital TV]] | sat chan 6 = Channel 606 | cable serv 2= [[Siti Cable]] |cable chan 2= Channel 447 }} [[File:hungamalogo.jpg|141px|thumb| Hungama TV's original 2004 logo, when it was under UTV Software Communications]] '''Hungama TV''' is a TV channel for children in India based in [[Mumbai]]. Originally a subsidiary of [[UTV Software Communications]] launched on September 26, 2004{{Cite news|url=https://www.financialexpress.com/archive/utv-launches-hungama-tv/61180/|title=UTV Launches Hungama TV|work=The Financial Express|access-date=2018-06-22|language=en-US}}, the channel was sold to [[Disney]] in 2006.{{cite web|url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/walt-disney-offers-to-acquire-utv-for-about-rs-2000-crore/822896|title=Walt Disney offers to acquire it for about rs 2000 crore|accessdate=21 May 2017}} Disney then bought UTV in 2011 thus reuniting UTV and Hungama TV under same ownership of Disney. Hungama TV is now an operating unit of [[Disney Channels Worldwide]]. It does not have an English audio track. ==History== [[UTV Software Communications|UTV]] and [[Ronnie Screwvala]] formed United Home Entertainment with 51% and 49% ownership interests respectively. United Home was formed to launch an Indian children's channel. The company hired TAG for channel packaging. Chief Operating Officer Purnendu Bose was hired and was expected to hire 100 employees for the channel. Rs 100 crore was the expected initial investment with expectations of break even in three years. In September 2004, Hungama TV started broadcasting as the first domestic children's channel.{{cite news|last1=Bansal|first1=Shuchi|title=Hungama TV to fight for ad share|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/hungama-tv-to-fight-for-ad-share-104040901069_1.html|accessdate=May 24, 2017|work=Business Standard India|date=9 April 2004|location=New Delhi}} In March 2005, one of the UTV founders, Zarina Mehta became head of programming for Hungama. In early 2006, Mehta was promoted to chief operating officer of the channel.{{cite news|last1=Adesara|first1=Hetal|title=Hungama TV COO Zarina Mehta|url=http://www.indiantelevision.com/special/y2k6/ms_media/zarina.htm|accessdate=May 24, 2017|work=Indian Television|date=May 27, 2006}} In July 2006, [[Disney India]] acquired a controlling stake in Hungama TV from [[UTV Software Communications]] Limited while also taking a 14.9% share in UTV.{{cite news|last=Leahy|first=Joe|title=Disney switches on to Hindi market|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/1114f6f4-4347-11db-9574-0000779e2340.html|accessdate=11 May 2014|newspaper=Financial Times|date=13 September 2006|author2=Sundeep Tucker}} In 2006, Disney acquired Hungama TV from UTV.{{cite news|last=Sinha|first=Ashish|title='UTV investment is long-term play'|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/technology/-utv-investment-is-long-term-play-108061801044_1.html|accessdate=April 23, 2014|newspaper=Business Standard|date=June 18, 2008}} The channel started with both live-action and animated programming but, following the success of ''[[Doraemon]]'', gradually shifted its focus to solely animated programming.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiantelevision.com/headlines/y2k4/sep/sep229.htm|title=Hungama TV banking on movies, four driver shows|date=September 21, 2004|accessdate=December 28, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.afaqs.com/news/story/12801_Hungama-TV-to-focus-on-animation-now|title=Hungama TV to focus on animation now|date=September 28, 2005|accessdate=May 12, 2018}} In 2013 Hungama started adding original Indian series as a part of a localisation strategy.{{cite news|title=Hungama TV gets new look, plans to add local shows {{!}} TelevisionPost.com|url=http://www.televisionpost.com/television/hungama-tv-gets-new-look-plans-to-add-local-shows/|accessdate=May 24, 2017|work=Television Post|date=October 10, 2013|location=Mumbai}} ==Programming== {{Main article|List of programmes broadcast by Hungama TV}} == Controversy == A Hindi dub of the Shin Chan anime started airing on Hungama TV on June 19, 2006, and it gained up to 60% of the channel's market share. {{Cite web|url=http://corporate.disney.in/disney-companies/media-networks/kids-channels/recent-shows|title=Shin Chan on Hungama TV - Disney India|last=|first=|date=|website=corporate.disney.in|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-12-09}} There were complaints from parents over the main character's behavior and the attitudes exhibited towards elders on the show, both of which were seen as a negative influence on children. The show was banned from Indian television in 2008.{{Cite web|url=http://www.merinews.com/article/india-bans-telecasting-of-shin-chan/151557.shtml|title=India bans telecasting of Shin Chan|website=www.merinews.com|access-date=2017-12-09}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.hungamatv.com}} {{Disney Channel}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hungama TV}} [[Category:Television stations in Mumbai]] [[Category:Children's television channels in India]] [[Category:Disney Channel]] [[Category:Indian animation]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 2004]] [[Category:2004 establishments in India]] [[Category:Disney India Media Networks]]

{{Infobox writer | name = Janis Hirsch | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1950}} | birth_place = Trenton, New Jersey | occupation = Producer, writer | alma_mater = | spouse = Larry Shulman | children = Charlie Shulman | years_active = }}
'''Janis Hirsch''' (born c. 1950) is a comedy writer best known for producing and writing for television series, including ''[[Frasier]], [[Will & Grace]], [[My Wife and Kids]], [[Anything but Love|Anything But Love]]'', ''[[L.A. Law|LA Law]]'', ''[[The Nanny]]'', ''[['Til Death|Til Death]]'', ''[[Square Pegs]]'', the [[National Lampoon's Vacation (film series)|''National Lampoon'' show]], ''[[Murphy Brown]]'', and ''[[It's Garry Shandling's Show]]''.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://skylighttheatrecompany.com/about-us/our-artists/482-janis-hirsch.html|title=Janis Hirsch|website=skylighttheatrecompany.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-01-15}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://360.rollins.edu/people/tales-of-a-female-comedy-writer|title=Tales of a Female Comedy Writer - People - Rollins 360|website=360.rollins.edu|access-date=2018-01-15}}</ref><ref name=":4" /> She has written books and for several publications including the ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' and [[National Lampoon (magazine)|''National Lampoon'' magazine]].
== About == Hirsch had [[Poliomyelitis|polio]] when she was 10 months old and uses crutches to walk.<ref name=":1" /> She is Jewish and was born in [[Trenton, New Jersey]].<ref name="Lowry">{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/news/tv-writers-childhood-letter-to-jackie-is-part-of-tlc-special-1200834118/|title=TV Writer’s Childhood Letter to Jackie Kennedy Is Part of TLC Special|last=Lowry|first=Brian|date=2013-11-15|work=Variety|access-date=2018-01-19|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/barbra-streisand-bette-midler-janis-404362|title=Barbra Streisand, Bette Midler, New Movies and Noses: A Sitcom Writer's Jew Review (Guest Column)|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2018-01-19|language=en}}</ref> In 1963, when she was 13, Hirsch wrote a condolence letter to [[Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis|Jackie Kennedy]] after the assassination of [[John F. Kennedy]].<ref name="Lowry"/> Hirsch was raised in [[Ewing Township, New Jersey|Ewing Township]], where she graduated from [[Ewing High School (New Jersey)|Ewing High School]] in 1968.<ref>Morris, Shaheed M. [https://www.trentonian.com/article/TT/20131116/NEWS/131119675 "City woman's 50-year-old letter part of TLC Kennedy special"], ''[[The Trentonian]]'', November 16, 2013. Accessed January 15, 2018. "Hirsch was born in Trenton. She graduated from Ewing High School in 1968."</ref> She said she left as soon as she could, and attended and graduated from [[Rollins College]] in [[Winter Park, Florida|Winter Park]], Florida.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://seejane.org/membership/salon-changing-the-lens-why-diversity-matters/|title=Salon - Changing the Lens: Why Diversity Matters - See Jane|work=See Jane|access-date=2018-01-15|language=en-US}}</ref> She worked for the ''[[Coconut Grove Playhouse]]''. She then worked for burlesque dancer [[Ann Corio]] in Massachusetts as a manager.
Hirsch relocated to New York and started working for the [[National Lampoon's Vacation (film series)|''National Lampoon'' show]] and then for the [[National Lampoon (magazine)|''National Lampoon'' magazine]].
She wrote two of the first six episodes of ''[[It's Garry Shandling's Show]]'', each of which received media praise, but she left the show soon after. In the wake of widespread 2017 media coverage of [[Harvey Weinstein sexual abuse allegations]], Hirsch revealed that she had not left her writing position by choice. After writing two acclaimed episodes (of the first six) of ''It's Garry Shandling's Show'', she was cut from meetings and not allowed to write any parts except for occasional single scenes with women. She stated that one day she was sitting across from [[Garry Shandling]] in his office, and one of the actors on the show unexpectedly approached her from behind and placed his flaccid penis on her shoulder. Producer [[Brad Grey]] forced Hirsch to quit from her writing position the next day, without pay.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/comedy-writer-reveals-lurid-details-harassment-set-why-it-cost-her-a-job-guest-column-1049647|title=Comedy Writer Reveals Lurid Details of Harassment on Set — and Why It Cost Her a Job (Guest Column)|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2018-01-15|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-11-11/comedy-writers-defend-say-anything-culture-in-sensitive-times|title=Comedy Writers Defend Say-Anything Culture in Sensitive Times|date=2017-11-11|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-01-15}}</ref>
Hirsch wrote contributions for comedy books, as well as publications like ''[[The New York Times]]''. She once lent $300 to [[John Belushi]] to fly to an audition for ''[[Animal House]]'' in California. She moved to Los Angeles and started writing for ''[[Square Pegs]]''.<ref name=":1" />
She has produced or written for ''[[Frasier]]'', ''[[Will & Grace]]'', ''[[My Wife and Kids]]'', ''[[Anything But Love]]'', ''[[L.A. Law]]'', ''[[The Nanny]], [[Murphy Brown]],'' and ''[['Til Death]].''<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":4" />
Hirsch has said that acceptance of women in the industry is greater now than in the 1970s when she started.<ref name=":1" /> She has been noted for using her clout to demand women not be ostracized or harassed on set, and she regularly mentors women in the comedy industry.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> Hirsch is a vocal supporter of several programs aimed at helping people with [[Poliomyelitis|polio]], [[Alzheimer's disease|Alzheimer’s]] or disabilities.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/21/opinion/disabled-on-broadway.html|title=Opinion {{!}} Disabled on Broadway|date=2017-04-21|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-15|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> She supports ''Faith in America'' and other causes to end religious prejudice and hate towards members of the gay community.<ref name=":1" />
She lives with her husband Larry Shulman in [[Los Angeles]] with their two dogs.<ref name=":3" />

{{Infobox video game | title = Jet-Story | image = File:JetstoryCover.jpg | developer = Cybexlab Software | publisher = [[Ultrasoft]] | modes = [[Single-player]] | director = | designer = Miroslav Fídler | writer = | programmer = | composer = [[František Fuka]] | engine = | platforms = [[ZX Spectrum]] | released = 1988 | genre = [[Action video game|Action]] }} '''''Jet-Story''''' is a 1988 video game developed by Cybexlab Software and published by [[Ultrasoft]]. The game is the sequel to ''Planet of Shades''.<ref name=ZX>{{cite web|title=Jet-Story|url=http://www.zx-spectrum.cz/index.php?cat1=3&cat2=3&game_id=jetstory.txt|website=ZX-Spectrum Games|accessdate=30 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=world>{{cite web|title=Jet-Story|url=http://www.worldofspectrum.org/infoseekid.cgi?id=0002612|website=World of Spectrum|accessdate=30 March 2015}}</ref>
==Development== Th game was developed in 1988. The Main Author is Miroslav Fídler who was helped by [[František Fuka]] and Tomáš Rylek. Fuka created opening Screen and Composed Music. In 1992 rights to the Game were bought by Ultrasoft that re-released the Game.<ref name=ZX/> ==Gameplay== The player controls a spacecraft in a huge maze. His task is to destroy 47 enemy bases scattered across the game world that contains 128 areas. The task is not easy as the maze is full of enemies. The player can use weapons to destroy them but has limited amount of ammo. Ammo, fuel, and health can be replenished by boxes scattered throughout the world. The game features realistic gravity.<ref name=bit>{{cite journal|title=Jet-Story|journal=Bit|date=February 1992|volume=5|page=26|url=http://www.oldgames.sk/mag/bit-5/page/26/|accessdate=30 March 2015}}</ref>
==Reception== The game has been well received. Bit Magazine gave the game 84%. The game was praised mostly for its gameplay and music. The graphics didn't gain such praise due to its simplicity.<ref name=world/><ref name=bit/>

The '''Junction Theatre Company''' was South Australia’s first professional [[community theatre]] company, founded in 1984.<ref>"New Theatre Company Formed", The Advertiser, Sunday October 6, 1984, Page 10</ref>
Junction Theatre Company created touring works in schools, factories and other workplaces, with an aim to “create theatre of a high artistic quality which is accessible to those sections of the community who have not traditionally participated in theatre as an accessible option for entertainment, learning and expressing issues” <ref>"Junction Theatre Company Annual Report 1990", State Library of South Australia</ref>
In its early days Junction Theatre was one of the country's main proponents of work supported by the program of funding Art and Working Life,<ref>Geoffrey Milne, Theatre Australia (un)limited: Australian Theatre Since the 1950s, Rodopi 2004</ref> along with companies such as [[Melbourne Workers Theatre]] in Victoria. The Art and Working Life funding program supported projects created in partnership with Trade Unions. Through the use of its own venue, it also became known as having an important role in facilitating the work of smaller companies in South Australia <ref>Don Rubin, Chua Soo Pong, Ravi Chaturvedi, The World Encyclopedia of Contemporary Theatre: Asia/Pacific, Taylor & Francis 2001</ref>
Junction Theatre Company’s first Artistic Director was Malcolm Blaylock.<ref>Geoffrey Milne, Theatre Australia (un)limited: Australian Theatre Since the 1950s, Rodopi 2004</ref> The subsequent and artistic director was Geoff Crowhurst, who was in the role until the closure of the company in 2001. Geoff Crowhurst was considered “A master of making theatre work for the good of whole communities”,<ref>"[http://www.australiacouncil.gov.au/news/media-centre/media-releases/australia-council-mourns-geoff-crowhurst/ AUSTRALIA COUNCIL MOURNS GEOFF CROWHURST]"</ref> and had an [[Arts South Australia]] Ruby Award category posthumously named in his honour for individuals who make "an outstanding contribution to community cultural development” <ref>[http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/ruby-awards-have-an-art-of-glass-for-10th-anniversary/news-story/9a8dc45affee457c81ddced45df9a66f "Ruby Awards have an art of glass for 10th Anniversary"] The Advertiser</ref>
Productions by Junction Theater Company include:
* The company's first production, ''Next Year's Model'' in 1984, about the gradual closure of the General Motors Holden plant in Woodville, Victoria <ref>[https://www.ausstage.edu.au/pages/event/60962 "AusStage Database" ]</ref> * ''The Keys to the Animal Room'' by Peta Murray, 1993, about an abusive marital relationship, which received the 1994 Gold [[AWGIE Awards|AWGIE Award]] <ref>[https://australianplays.org/playwright/CP-murken "Peta Murray | Australian Plays Online" ]</ref> * ''Hello Down There'' in 1993, a play about the collapse of the [[State Bank of South Australia]], which was named 'Best Community Theatre for 1993' in The Advertiser <ref>Junction Theatre Company Annual Report, 1993, pp 6</ref> * The company's last production, ''Love Land and Money'', 2002, relating to themes of reconciliation and mining industries,<ref>[http://murraybramwell.com/?p=322 "The Adelaide Review, No.222, March, 2002. pp.22-23" ]</ref> co-presented by [[Adelaide Fringe Festival]] and [[Tandanya National Aboriginal Cultural Institute]]

{{Redirect|Lumière Award|the film festival accolade|Lumière Award (film festival award)}} {{Infobox Award | name = Lumières Award | image = | caption = | current_awards = 23rd Lumières Awards | description = Excellence in [[Francophone]] [[film|cinema]] | presenter = [[Académie des Lumières]] | country = [[France]] | year = 1996 | website = {{url|academiedeslumieres.com}} }} The '''Lumières Award''' ({{lang-fr|Prix Lumières}}) (sometimes called the ''Prix Lumière'' or ''Lumière Award'') is a [[France|French]] [[film award]] presented by the ''Académie des Lumières'' to honor the best in the [[French language|French-speaking cinema]] of the previous year. The awards ceremony is organized by the Académie des Lumières which consists of over 200 representatives of the international press based in [[Paris]]. Today it is regarded as one of the most prestigious [[French film industry]] awards, equivalent to the [[Golden Globe Award]] presented by the [[Hollywood Foreign Press Association]]. ==History == The Lumières Award was initiated in 1995 by French producer [[Daniel Toscan du Plantier]] and American journalist and ex-[[Newsweek]]'s Paris correspondent [[Edward Behr (journalist)|Edward Behr]]. Their idea was to replicate the [[Golden Globes]] given by the foreign press in Hollywood.[http://www.academielumieres.com/l__academie_des_lumieres_du_cinema.ws L'Académie des Lumières] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017225322/http://www.academielumieres.com/l__academie_des_lumieres_du_cinema.ws |date=2013-10-17 }} "À l'image des Golden Globe Awards décernés chaque année par l'Association de la presse étrangère de Hollywood, l'Académie des Lumières veut souligner le grand intérêt que porte au cinéma français la presse internationale largement représentée à Paris." The Lumières Award is usually presented a month before [[César Award]], the French national film award. == Background == === Directing board === The president of the academy is Grazyna Arata, the vice-presidents are Pauline Guilmot and Denitza Bantcheva, and the general secretary is Michela Secci. ==Award categories== === Current categories === *[[Lumières Award for Best Film|Best Film]]: since 1996 *[[Lumières Award for Best Director|Best Director]]: since 1996 *[[Lumières Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]]: since 1996 *[[Lumières Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]]: since 1996 *[[Lumières Award for Best Screenplay|Best Screenplay]]: since 1996 *[[Lumières Award for Most Promising Actor|Most Promising Actor]]: since 2000 *[[Lumières Award for Most Promising Actress|Most Promising Actress]]: since 2000 *[[Lumières Award for Best French-Language Film|Best French-Language Film]]: since 2003 *[[Lumières Award for Best First Film|Best First Film (Prix Heike Hurst)]]: since 2014 *[[Lumières Award for Best Cinematography|Best Cinematography (Prix CST)]]: since 2008 *Best Music: since 2016 *Best Documentary: since 2016 *Special Jury Prize: since 2013 *Honorary Lumières Award: since 2006 === Discontinued categories === * World Audience Award * Best Foreign Film == Ceremonies== {{Refimprove|section|date=June 2015}} {| class="sortable wikitable center" !
