'''Moving Image Source''' is a website of the [[Museum of the Moving Image (New York City)]] devoted to the history of [[film]], [[television]], and [[digital media]]. Made possible with support from the Hazen Polsky Foundation, it features original articles by leading critics, authors, and scholars; a calendar that highlights major [[retrospective]]s, festivals, and gallery exhibitions at venues around the world; and a regularly updated guide to online research resources. Film critic [[Dennis Lim]] currently serves as editor-in-chief.<ref>Greencine {{cite web |url=http://daily.greencine.com/archives/006179.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-07-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080611113940/http://daily.greencine.com/archives/006179.html |archivedate=2008-06-11 |df= }}</ref>
The launch of Moving Image Source was marked by a special program at [[The Times Center]] in Manhattan at 6:30 p.m. on June 5, featuring a conversation between directors [[Werner Herzog]] (''Encounters at the End of the World'', opening June 11) and [[Jonathan Demme]] (''[[The Silence of the Lambs (film)|The Silence of the Lambs]]'').
Moving Image Source is updated every Thursday with additions to the Articles and Calendar sections.
== Articles ==
The articles relate to recent and ongoing retrospectives and gallery exhibitions as well as to significant new DVDs and books on film, media, and moving-image culture. Pieces are accompanied by photographs, video clips, and sidebars offering suggestions for further viewing, reading, or listening. June contributors included critics and authors Melissa Anderson, [[Michael Atkinson (writer)|Michael Atkinson]], [[Joshua Clover]], [[Tom Charity]], Thomas Doherty, [[Chris Fujiwara]], [[Ed Halter]], [[B. Kite]], [[Michael Koresky]], Rob Nelson, [[Nick Pinkerton]], [[Tony Rayns]], [[Jonathan Rosenbaum]], [[Dan Sallitt]], and [[Ed Sikov]]. Topics included the career of [[Werner Herzog]], Wallis-Hazen Productions, a reappraisal of the ’60s films of [[William Klein (photographer)|William Klein]], the late Taiwanese filmmaker [[Edward Yang]], video artist [[Eddo Stern]], the late films of [[Howard Hawks]], Japanese actor [[Tatsuya Nakadai]], and the recent restoration of [[Max Ophüls]]’s [[Lola Montès]].<ref>From http://www.movingimagesource.us/articles</ref>
== Calendar == The Moving Image Source Calendar is a selective guide to major screenings, series, [[festivals]], and gallery exhibitions. Calendar entries include program summaries, exhibition descriptions, titles of films or featured works of media art, and links to presenting venues. The Calendar draws on the programming of more than 100 [[museums]], media arts centers, [[cinematheques]], and other venues around the world that regularly present film and media programs.<ref>From http://www.movingimagesource.us/events</ref> An international Venue List can be found in the Calendar section: Venues on the list emphasize original programming and the presentation of work in its original format, and/or large-scale gallery exhibitions.<ref>From http://www.movingimagesource.us/events/venues</ref>
== Research Guide == The site's Research Guide is an annotated and regularly maintained database of more than 400 moving-image related resources on the web, ranging from scholarly and popular journals to film-related libraries and archives. They have been organized into a detailed, easy-to-navigate [[Taxonomy (general)|taxonomy]] with five primary categories: “People,” “History and Styles,” “Industry,” “Technology and Craft,” and “[[Criticism]] and Ideas.” The Research Guide may also be browsed by resource type, and advanced search and filtering options are available.<ref>From http://www.movingimagesource.us/research</ref>
== External links == Moving Image Source [http://www.movingimagesource.us]

It was produced by Full Moon Entertainment and was shot in Romania. It is a sequel to the 1994 film ''[[Oblivion (1994 film)|Oblivion]]''. ==Synopsis== In the alien-western world of Oblivion, a suave, yet lethal bounty hunter named Sweeney arrives to arrest the seductive outlaw Lash on multiple charges, including murder. Lash, who just "inherited" a mine of Derconium (the most valuable mineral in the universe) from Crowley in a game of cards, meets up with Redeye's brother, Jaggar, who wants the mine for himself to rule the galaxy. It's a fight over Lash between the sheriff of Oblivion, Jaggar, and Sweeney. {{See also|Index of literature articles}} The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to literature: '''[[Literature]]''' – [[prose]], written or [[oral literature|oral]], including [[fiction]] and [[non-fiction]], [[drama]], and [[poetry]]. ''See also: [[outline of poetry]].'' {{TOC limit|limit=2}} == What ''type'' of thing is literature? == Literature can be described as all of the following: * [[Communication]] – activity of conveying information. Communication requires a sender, a message, and an intended recipient, although the receiver need not be present or aware of the sender's intent to communicate at the time of communication; thus communication can occur across vast distances in time and space. ** [[Written communication]] (writing) – representation of language in a textual medium through the use of a set of signs or symbols (known as a writing system).Peter T. Daniels, "The Study of Writing Systems", in ''The World's Writing Systems'', ed. Bright and Daniels, p. 3 * Subdivision of [[culture]] – shared attitudes, values, goals, and practices that characterizes an institution, organization, or group. ** One of [[the arts]] – imaginative, creative, or nonscientific branch of knowledge, especially as studied academically.[http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/the-arts the arts]. Cardinal Beppi Pelle |writers = [[Jonathan Hickman]] |artists = Jonathan Hickman |pencillers = |inkers = |letterers = Jonathan Hickman |colorists = Jonathan Hickman |editors = |creative_team_month = |creative_team_year = |creators = Jonathan Hickman |TPB = Pax Romana |ISBN = 1-58240-873-4 |TPB# = |ISBN# = |subcat = Image Comics |altcat = |sort = Pax Romana |addpubcat# = |nonUS = }} '''''Pax Romana''''' is a creator-owned four-issue [[Limited series (comics)|limited series]] [[American comic book|comic book]] written and illustrated by [[Jonathan Hickman]] and published by [[Image Comics]] on March 7, 2012. ==Plot== Vatican-backed research has discovered the secret of time travel. With it the Church plans to fix the future by altering the past. They send a warehouse of modern weaponry and enhanced soldiers to Rome in 312AD. Plans change quickly as the cardinal in charge of the mission is shot. ==Collected editions== {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan=4|Trade paperbacks |- ! Title !! Material collected !! Publication date !! ISBN |- |''Pax Romana'' || ''Pax Romana'' #1–4 || April 2008 || {{ISBN|1-58240-873-4}} |} ==Adaptation== On April 30, 2014, [[Syfy]] announced they would be adapting Pax Romana into a miniseries.{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/04/syfy-developing-pax-romana-miniseries-the-magicians-series/|title=SyFy developing Pax Romana miniseries|date= April 2014}} Matthew Federman and Stephen Scaia (''Warehouse 13'') are writing the show, with Scaia and David Alpert (''The Walking Dead'') executive producing. Hickman will serve as a co-executive producer.{{cite web|url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=52503/|title=SyFy developing Pax Romana and More|date=April 20, 2014}} ==Characters== {{main article|List of Pax Romana characters}} ;Nicholas Chase: A retired American general who is sent with Cardinal Beppi Pelle on a mission from the Pope to change history and right the wrongs of modern humanity by ensuring that the Catholic Church reigns supreme. ;Gene Pope: Pope who tells the young Holy Roman Emperor the story of how the empire has lasted for so many centuries. ;Beppi Pelle: Cardinal chosen to be sent back in time to make sure the Catholic Church retains supremacy. ;Constantine: [[Constantine I|Constantine]] was the first Christian emperor of Rome. Considered within the story to be the last effective ruler of Rome. ==References== {{Reflist}} ===Interviews=== * [http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=11719 Hickman Saves the Future, Destroys the Past in "Pax Romana"], [[Comic Book Resources]], October 16, 2007 ===Reviews=== * [http://www.aintitcool.com/node/35233#5 Jonathan Hickman: The Design of Things to Come], ''[[Ain't It Cool News]]'', January 9, 2008 ==External links== *[http://www.pronea.com/pr.html Foreword and preview of the collected edition] *{{gcdb series|id=28809|title=Pax Romana}} *{{comicbookdb|type=title|id=16563|title=Pax Romana}} {{Image-Comics-stub}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pax Romana}} [[Category:Comics by Jonathan Hickman]] [[Category:Comics about time travel]] [[Category:Image Comics stubs]] [[Category:Science fiction comics]] [[Category:Action comics]]

[[File:Asiana Boeing 747-400 Seat Plan.svg|thumb|right|250px|Seating plan for a [[Boeing 747-400]]]] A '''seating plan''' is a [[diagram]] or a set of written or spoken instructions that determines where people should take their seats. It is widely used on diverse occasions.
Seating plans have a wide range of purposes. At formal [[dinner]]s, they are usually used to avoid chaos and confusion upon entrance and to follow the [[etiquette]]. In this case, it is customary to arrange the [[Hospitality|host]] and hostess at the opposite sides of the table, and alternate male and female guests throughout.<ref>{{Cite book|author=Oretha D. Swartz|title=Service Etiquette|publisher=Naval Institute Press|year=1988|isbn=9780870216206|pages=267-278}}</ref> [[Place card]]s can be used to direct guests. [[State dinner]]s have their own protocol and arrangements are made so that the most distinguished guests can have the possibility to engage in conversation. Plans are also made for [[airplanes]], where the objective is to differentiate [[passenger]]s between the various [[Travel class|travel classes]] and ensure everybody has a place. Similarly, [[theatre]]s or [[movie theatre|cinema]]s may allow spectators to choose their seats beforehand. A seating plan is of crucial importance for [[musical ensemble]]s or [[orchestra]]s, where every type of [[Musical instrument|instrument]] is allocated a specific section.<ref>{{cite book|title=Teaching Band & Orchestra: Methods and Materials|author=Lynn G. Cooper|publisher=GIA Publications|year=2004|isbn=9781579992750|page=251}}</ref>

{{good article}} {{Infobox company | name = Tectoy S.A. | logo = [[Image:Tectoy 2007 logo.png|center|200px]] | former_name = Tec Toy | type = [[S.A. (corporation)|Sociedade Anônima]] | traded_as = [[B3 (stock exchange)|B3]]: [https://web.archive.org/web/20160303224309/http://www.bmfbovespa.com.br/pt-br/mercados/acoes/empresas/ExecutaAcaoConsultaInfoEmp.asp?CodCVM=14133 TOYB4] | foundation = 1987 | location = [[São Paulo]], [[Brazil]] | key_people = Daniel Dazcal
Stefano Arnhold
Fernando Fischer Pereira | num_employees = | industry = [[Toys]], [[Video games]], [[Electronics]] | products = [[Sega Master System|Master System]], [[Mega Drive|Genesis/Mega Drive]], [[Sega Game Gear|Game Gear]], [[Sega Saturn|Saturn]], [[Dreamcast]], [[Zeebo]] | revenue = | net_income = | homepage = [https://web.archive.org/web/20141223030004/http://www.tectoy.com.br/en/ www.tectoy.com.br] }} '''Tectoy''' (known as '''Tec Toy''' before late 2007) is a Brazilian toy and electronics company headquartered in [[São Paulo]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.tectoy.com.br/termos.php|title=Termos de Uso|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Tectoy|language=Portuguese|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090901064638/http://www.tectoy.com.br/termos.php|archive-date=September 1, 2009|dead-url=yes|access-date=October 3, 2009|df=}} It is best known for producing, publishing, and distributing [[Sega]] consoles and video games in [[Brazil]]. The company was founded by Daniel Dazcal, Leo Kryss, and Abe Kryss in 1987 because Dazcal saw an opportunity to develop a market for electronic toys and video games, product categories that competitors did not sell in Brazil at the time. The company stock is traded on the [[Bovespa]]. Soon after its founding, Tectoy completed a licensing agreement with Sega allowing it to market a laser gun game based on the Japanese anime [[Zillion (anime)|''Zillion'']], which sold more units in Brazil than in Japan. Tectoy would later bring the [[Master System]] and [[Sega Genesis|Mega Drive]] to the region, as well as Sega's later video game consoles and the [[Sega Meganet]] service. Other products developed by Tectoy include educational toys such as the Pense Bem, karaoke machines, and original Master System and Mega Drive games released exclusively in Brazil, such as ''[[Férias Frustradas do Pica-Pau]]'' and Portuguese translations and alternate versions of video games. Over its history, Tectoy has diversified to include more electronic products, such as [[DVD player|DVD]] and [[Blu-ray|Blu-ray players]] and the [[Zeebo]] console. While successful at times, the company has also undergone [[debt restructuring]] in 2000 and actions to consolidate its two public stock offerings into one. Tectoy is credited with the continued success of Sega consoles in Brazil far past their lifetimes worldwide. At one point, Tectoy held an 80% market share of video games in Brazil. The Master System and Mega Drive are still produced in Brazil decades after their cancellation in the rest of the world, and Tectoy's consoles continue to rival more modern systems by [[Microsoft]] and [[Sony]] in popularity. ==History== [[Image:Tec Toy logo old.jpg|thumb|Tectoy's original logo from 1987 to 2000]] === Formation and early years (1987-1996) === Tectoy was founded in September 1987 by Daniel Dazcal, Leo Kryss, and Abe Kryss. Dazcal was previously associated with [[Sharp Corporation]] in Brazil, while the Kryss brothers were the owners of Evadin, a Brazilian TV manufacturer associated with [[Mitsubishi]]. The new startup company sought to create "intelligent toys" designed specifically for the Brazilian market.{{Cite magazine|last=Szczepaniak|first=John|date=November 2006|title=Company Profile: Tec Toy|url=|magazine=[[Retro Gamer]]|publisher=[[Imagine Publishing]]|issue=30|pages=50–53|doi=|issn=1742-3155|pmid=|access-date=}} At the time, Brazil's most dominant toy manufacturer was [[Estrela (company)|Estrela]], which held 55% of the market share but did not have any interest in electronics. This gave Dazcal an area to focus the new company. In order to give the company an advantage in marketing costs, Tectoy set its factory in the [[Free Economic Zone of Manaus]] to leverage tax incentives. One of the primary goals of the founders of the company was to enter the video game market. Relying on individual previous experiences in working with Japanese companies, Tectoy executives reached out to [[Sega]], which initially showed reluctance to partner with Tectoy given the failure of [[Tonka]] in merchandising Sega products in the United States. The company slowly built trust with Sega and was ultimately granted total liberty to manage Sega products in the Brazilian market. The first Sega product released by Tectoy was the ''Zillion'' infrared [[laser tag]] gun, based on the phaser featured in [[Zillion (anime)|the anime of the same name]]. The success of ''Zillion'' led Sega to have Tectoy distribute its 8-bit video game console, the [[Master System]], in Brazil as well. Launched officially in Brazil in September 1989, the Master System achieved success.{{Cite web|url=http://jogos.uol.com.br/playstation3/ultnot/2009/09/04/ult530u7180.jhtm|title=Master System completa 20 anos de vida no Brasil|last=|first=|date=September 4, 2009|website=[[Universo Online]]|publisher=[[Grupo Folha]]|language=Portuguese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227035251/http://jogos.uol.com.br/playstation3/ultnot/2009/09/04/ult530u7180.jhtm|archivedate=February 27, 2014|deadurl=no|accessdate=February 21, 2014|df=}} Tectoy's revenue in 1989 was [[Brazilian cruzado|Cz$]]66 million,{{cite news|url=https://acervo.estadao.com.br/publicados/1989/12/20/g/19891220-35228-nac-0046-eco-10-not-skhwggs.jpg|title=Tec Toy ultrapassa suas metas|last=Aguiar|first=Isabel Dias de|date=December 20, 1989|newspaper=[[O Estado de S.Paulo]]|access-date=|publisher=Grupo Estado|issue=35228|location=São Paulo|volume=110|page=46|language=Portuguese|issn=1516-2931|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303192502/http://acervo.estadao.com.br/publicados/1989/12/20/g/19891220-35228-nac-0046-eco-10-not-skhwggs.jpg|archive-date=March 3, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} of which Cz$40 million was attributed to the console. Some of this success is attributed to the company's strong advertising investments: the launch campaign, which lasted until Christmas 1989, was at an expense of Cz$2 million.{{cite news|url=https://acervo.estadao.com.br/publicados/1989/09/13/g/19890913-35144-nac-0044-eco-12-not-qhhhhas.jpg|title=Chega o jogo em 3ª dimensão|last=Jaggi|first=Marlene|date=September 13, 1989|newspaper=O Estado de S.Paulo|access-date=|publisher=Grupo Estado|issue=35144|location=São Paulo|volume=110|page=44|language=Portuguese|issn=1516-2931|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303172242/http://acervo.estadao.com.br/publicados/1989/09/13/g/19890913-35144-nac-0044-eco-12-not-qhhhhas.jpg|archive-date=March 3, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} By the end of 1990, the Master System install base in Brazil was about 280,000 units.{{cite news|url=https://acervo.estadao.com.br/publicados/1990/11/22/g/19901122-35513-nac-0081-eco-9-not-aaweass.jpg|title=Tec Toy lança no País o videogame Mega Drive|last=|first=|date=November 22, 1990|newspaper=O Estado de S.Paulo|access-date=|publisher=Grupo Estado|issue=35513|location=São Paulo|volume=111|page=81|language=Portuguese|issn=1516-2931|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304063644/http://acervo.estadao.com.br/publicados/1990/11/22/g/19901122-35513-nac-0081-eco-9-not-aaweass.jpg|archive-date=March 4, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} The company also introduced a telephone service with tips for games, created a Master System club, and presented the program ''Master Tips'' during commercial breaks of the television show ''Sessão Aventura'' of [[Rede Globo]]. Over a year after the launch of the Master System, Tectoy officially brought Sega's 16-bit console, the [[Sega Genesis|Mega Drive]], to Brazil in December 1990. Sega's handheld console, Game Gear, was later released in August 1991.{{cite news|url=https://acervo.estadao.com.br/publicados/1991/10/15/g/19911015-35791-nac-0041-eco-9-not-sahaxps.jpg|title=Game Boy chega às lojas Mesbla|last=|first=|date=October 15, 1991|newspaper=O Estado de S.Paulo|access-date=|publisher=Grupo Estado|issue=35791|location=São Paulo|volume=112|page=41|language=Portuguese|issn=1516-2931|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304083959/http://acervo.estadao.com.br/publicados/1991/10/15/g/19911015-35791-nac-0041-eco-9-not-sahaxps.jpg|archive-date=March 4, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} Like the Master System, the two products were assembled by Tectoy in Manaus, and Game Gear was the first portable console manufactured in Brazil.{{cite news|url=https://acervo.estadao.com.br/publicados/1991/09/01/g/19910901-35754-nac-0177-est-7-not-hppahsp.jpg|title=O primeiro portátil já está nas lojas|last=|first=|date=September 1, 1991|newspaper=O Estado de S.Paulo|access-date=|publisher=Grupo Estado|issue=35754|location=São Paulo|volume=112|page=177|language=Portuguese|issn=1516-2931|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303200518/http://acervo.estadao.com.br/publicados/1991/09/01/g/19910901-35754-nac-0177-est-7-not-hppahsp.jpg|archive-date=March 3, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} Sega's primary competition, [[Nintendo]], did not officially arrive in Brazil until 1993; they entered the region through Playtronic, a partnership between [[IGB Eletrônica|Gradiente]] and Estrela.{{cite news|url=http://acervo2.folha.com.br/7/61/8/78/4780861/1024/4780861.png|title=Estrela e Gradiente trazem jogos Nintendo|last=|first=|date=March 18, 1993|newspaper=[[Folha de S.Paulo]]|access-date=|publisher=Grupo Folha|issue=23360|location=São Paulo|volume=73|pages=2–13|language=Portuguese|issn=1414-5723|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303230509/http://acervo2.folha.com.br/7/61/8/78/4780861/1024/4780861.png|archive-date=March 3, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} By the time Nintendo arrived in the region, they were unable to compete with pirated [[Nintendo Entertainment System|NES]] systems already available in the region and Tectoy's established following. Mega Drive surpassed the [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System|SNES]] in market share in Brazil, and Tectoy claimed 80% of the local video game market.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sega-16.com/2015/11/interview-stefano-arnhold-tectoy/|title=Interview: Stefano Arnhold (Tectoy)|last=Sponsel|first=Sebastian|date=November 16, 2015|website=Sega-16|publisher=Ken Horowitz|accessdate=November 30, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151122012118/http://www.sega-16.com/2015/11/interview-stefano-arnhold-tectoy/|archivedate=November 22, 2015|df=}} By 1996, Tectoy had sold 2 million video game consoles and was receiving 50,000 calls a month to their video game tip line. On May 26, 1994, Dazcal died at the age of 42.{{cite news|url=http://acervo2.folha.com.br/5/14/97/95/4959714/1024/4959714.jpg|title=Comunicado de falecimento|last=|first=|date=May 27, 1994|newspaper=Folha de S.Paulo|access-date=|publisher=Grupo Folha|issue=23795|location=São Paulo|volume=74|pages=3–4|language=Portuguese|issn=1414-5723|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303230641/http://acervo2.folha.com.br/5/14/97/95/4959714/1024/4959714.jpg|archive-date=March 3, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} He was replaced as CEO by Stefano Arnhold, who had worked for Dazcal at Sharp and became one of Tectoy's earliest employees in December 1987.{{cite news|url=http://acervo2.folha.com.br/8/2/21/83/4832102/1024/4832102.png|title=Painel S/A: na presidência|last=|first=|date=August 18, 1994|newspaper=Folha de S.Paulo|access-date=|publisher=Grupo Folha|issue=23878|location=São Paulo|volume=74|pages=2-2|language=Portuguese|issn=1414-5723|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303230522/http://acervo2.folha.com.br/8/2/21/83/4832102/1024/4832102.png|archive-date=March 3, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} Arnhold continued Tectoy's partnership with Sega and released the [[Sega Saturn]] on August 30, 1995, at a price of [[Brazilian real|R$]]899.99.{{cite news|url=http://acervo2.folha.com.br/2/46/99/54/549946/1024/549946.png|title=Saturn já está nas lojas, mas é muito caro|last=Moura|first=Rosangela de|date=September 8, 1995|newspaper=Folha de S.Paulo|access-date=|publisher=Grupo Folha|issue=24264|location=São Paulo|volume=75|pages=6-3|language=Portuguese|issn=1414-5723|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303182325/http://acervo2.folha.com.br/2/46/99/54/549946/1024/549946.png|archive-date=March 3, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} With the increase in the number of commercial Internet users in Brazil, Tectoy also invested in content and Internet access by introducing a Brazilian version of [[Internet service provider]] [[CompuServe]], at the time the second largest US subscriber number. [[São Paulo]], [[Rio de Janeiro]], and [[Belo Horizonte]] were the first cities to receive the service.{{cite news|url=http://acervo2.folha.com.br/8/32/6/88/4880632/1024/4880632.png|title=CompuServe chega para prover acesso|last=|first=|date=April 9, 1997|newspaper=Folha de S.Paulo|access-date=|publisher=Grupo Folha|issue=24843|location=São Paulo|volume=77|pages=5–6|language=Portuguese|issn=1414-5723|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303201210/http://acervo2.folha.com.br/8/32/6/88/4880632/1024/4880632.png|archive-date=March 3, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} The service officially began in April 1997 and was part of a strategy to diversify the company's interests away from being a seasonal industry.{{cite web|url=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/fol/tec/ult200498044.htm|title=Universo Online absorve CompuServe Brasil|last=|first=|date=April 20, 1998|website=Folha de S.Paulo|publisher=Grupo Folha|location=São Paulo|language=Portuguese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303235808/http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/fol/tec/ult200498044.htm|archivedate=March 3, 2016|deadurl=no|accessdate=February 25, 2014|df=}} === Debt restructuring and changes in focus (1997-2006) === In 1997, Tectoy saw financial losses of R$35.9 million and saw a 32% drop in revenue compared to 1996,{{cite web|url=http://www.econoinfo.com.br/comunicados/TECTOY/Breve-Historico-da-Empresa/1001846354546?p=1|title=Breve histórico da empresa|last=|first=|date=August 3, 2012|website=Econoinfo|language=Portuguese|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ni6I0cQ8?url=http://www.econoinfo.com.br/comunicados/TECTOY/Breve-Historico-da-Empresa/1001846354546?p=1|archivedate=February 27, 2014|dead-url=yes|accessdate=February 27, 2014|df=}} a year in which the company also failed to meet its revenue goal.{{cite news|url=http://acervo2.folha.com.br/2/66/10/50/501066/1024/501066.png|title=Games ignoram mudanças na alíquota|last=Lucchesi|first=Cristiane Perini|date=July 21, 1996|newspaper=Folha de S.Paulo|access-date=|publisher=Grupo Folha|issue=24581|location=São Paulo|volume=76|pages=2–6|language=Portuguese|issn=1414-5723|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303171149/http://acervo2.folha.com.br/2/66/10/50/501066/1024/501066.png|archive-date=March 3, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} The company managed to reduce its losses in 1998, but still saw a net loss of R$10.8 million. During this period, the company launched the [[Dreamcast]] console in Brazil in September 1999 at a price of R$900.{{cite news|url=http://acervo2.folha.com.br/2/11/13/65/651311/1024/651311.png|title=Games|last=|first=|date=September 22, 1999|newspaper=Folha de S.Paulo|access-date=|publisher=Grupo Folha|issue=25739|location=São Paulo|volume=79|pages=5-3|language=Portuguese|issn=1414-5723|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310052828/http://acervo2.folha.com.br/2/11/13/65/651311/1024/651311.png|archive-date=March 10, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} To cut costs, the Brazilian version was released without a pack-in game and a modem for Internet connection.{{cite news|url=http://acervo2.folha.com.br/2/19/9/61/610919/1024/610919.png|title=Sega Dreamcast estoura nas lojas|last=Oliveira|first=Otavio Dias de|date=September 11, 1999|newspaper=Folha de S.Paulo|access-date=|publisher=Grupo Folha|issue=25728|location=São Paulo|volume=79|pages=5-3|language=Portuguese|issn=1414-5723|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303194536/http://acervo2.folha.com.br/2/19/9/61/610919/1024/610919.png|archive-date=March 3, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010709012832/http://www.tectoy.com.br/consoles/dreamcast/acessorios.html|url=http://www.tectoy.com.br/consoles/dreamcast/acessorios.html|publisher=Tec Toy|title=Dreamcast - Acessórios|archivedate=July 9, 2001|accessdate=February 28, 2014|language=Portuguese}} The modem would be released months later at a price of R$49.99. As of July 2000, Dreamcast sold about 20,000 units in Brazil.{{cite web|url=http://veja.abril.com.br/especiais/Digital3/jogos.html|publisher=Veja|title=A nova guerra mundial|date=August 2000|first=Edson|last=Rossi|accessdate=February 28, 2004|language=Portuguese|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030425195839/http://veja.abril.com.br/especiais/Digital3/jogos.html|archivedate=April 25, 2003|df=}} By 2000, Tectoy had debts of R$55 million. The difficulties presented by the market caused Tectoy to announce its application for [[debt restructuring]] on December 9, 1997. At the time, the reasons disclosed to the press were the drop in sales and interest in Tectoy's products.{{cite web|url=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/fsp/dinheiro/fi111222.htm|title=Tec Toy pede concordata|last=|first=|date=December 11, 1997|website=Folha de S.Paulo|publisher=Grupo Folha|location=São Paulo|language=Portuguese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310053456/http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/fsp/dinheiro/fi111222.htm|archivedate=March 10, 2014|deadurl=no|accessdate=February 27, 2014|df=}} The arrangement caused a number of Tectoy businesses to be restructured. CompuServe, which had opened the previous year in Brazil, was closed on April 25, 1998. Subscribers had the option of migrating to the competitor [[Universo Online]] (UOL).{{cite web|url=http://sobre.uol.com.br/ultnot/novidade/noticias/ult240498103.jhtm|accessdate=February 25, 2014|title=Universo Online assina cooperação com CompuServe internacional|website=Universo Online|publisher=Grupo Folha|date=April 24, 1998|language=Portuguese}} At the time of the closure, Arnhold stated that although the internet market was "promising", the company had not reached the number of subscribers that the company was expecting. As part of the debt restructuring, Tectoy renegotiated the debt up to six years for repayment, moved its factory in [[Manaus]] to smaller facilities, simplified its production chain, and cut its number of employees from 1000 to 110.{{cite web|url=http://www.istoedinheiro.com.br/noticias/9437_A+VOLTA+DA+TEC+TOY|title=A volta da Tec Toy|last=Simão|first=Juliana|date=February 1, 2002|website=IstoÉ Dinheiro|publisher=Editora Três|language=Portuguese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310051215/http://www.istoedinheiro.com.br/noticias/9437_A+VOLTA+DA+TEC+TOY|archivedate=March 10, 2014|deadurl=yes|accessdate=February 25, 2014|df=}} In Tectoy's offices in São Paulo, all employees were centralized to one location. Tectoy also narrowed its focus to video games and its new work on [[karaoke]] machines. The company became the first in Brazil to use compact discs as media for its karaoke devices, in contrast to the cartridge-based machines of its only domestic competitor, Raf Electronics.{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=November 28, 2000|title=Brazil: TecToy in the karaoque video market|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-67377046.html|journal=South American Business Information|publisher=Comtex News Network, Inc.|volume=|pages=C-10|via=[[HighBeam Research]]{{subscription required}}|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180625153416/https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-67377046.html|archivedate=June 25, 2018|df=}} With these restructuring changes, Tectoy was able to reduce its annual costs to R$4 million in 2001, half of what it spent in 1997, and bankruptcy procedures closed on October 4, 2000.{{cite newspaper|newspaper=Diário Oficial do Estado do Amazonas|publisher=Imprensa Oficial do Estado do Amazonas|page=14|date=October 4, 2000|volume=CVI|issue=29507|title=Autos de concordata preventiva Nº 14910-3/97|language=Portuguese|url=http://www.imprensaoficial.am.gov.br/|last=|first=|access-date=|location=Manaus|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180519170326/http://www.imprensaoficial.am.gov.br/|archive-date=May 19, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}[[Image:Tec Toy logo new.jpg|thumb|200px|Tectoy's second logo, 2001 to 2007|alt=|left]] After the end of bankruptcy proceedings, Tectoy announced another change to its focus. The company announced its diversification from focusing solely on toys and video games into an "entertainment company". Tectoy intended to introduce more product lines, including [[DVD player]]s, with a focus on higher profitability and less seasonality to the business. The company's video game business remained strong during this time; the year 2000 saw Tectoy make a 25% increase in sales of its Mega Drive console as compared to 1999. While a 2% sales decrease occurred in 2001 due to power rationing in Brazil, the company aimed for another 25% increase of its video game business the next year. By the year 2002, Tectoy had sold 1.2 million Mega Drives in Brazil, and aimed to produce another 100,000 units.{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=August 23, 2002|title=Tectoy aims to increase sales by 25% in Brazil over 2002|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-90685296.html|deadurl=no|journal=South American Business Information|publisher=Comtex News Network, Inc.|volume=|pages=|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180622005129/https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-90685296.html|archivedate=June 22, 2018|via=HighBeam Research{{subscription required}}|df=}} Part of the continued success of the Mega Drive came from Tectoy's partnership with Brazilian television station [[SBT (Brazil)|SBT]] to release a game based on ''Show do Milhão'', a popular game show. === Diversification and Zeebo (2006-2010) === In May 2007, Fernando Fischer became the company's president. He promised to reverse the R$3 million loss from the previous year, and increase revenue by R$45 million.{{cite web|url=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/folha/informatica/ult124u377555.shtml|title=Tectoy faz parceria com a Qualcomm|date=March 1, 2008|accessdate=February 25, 2014|website=Folha de S. Paulo|publisher=Grupo Folha|language=Portuguese}} At the same time, the company began using the name "Tectoy" as one word instead of two, and introduced a new logo. Tectoy set forth four business areas of focus in the digital entertainment field: video games, DVDs, digital TV receivers, and toys. One of the first new products was a mobile TV digital receiver, MobTV, in December 2007.{{cite web|url=http://propmark.uol.com.br/mercado/22521:tectoy-fara-concorrencia-para-agencia-em-2008|website=Propmark|publisher=Universo Online|title=Tectoy fará concorrência para agência em 2008|date=September 10, 2007|accessdate=February 25, 2014|language=Portuguese|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310054004/http://propmark.uol.com.br/mercado/22521:tectoy-fara-concorrencia-para-agencia-em-2008|archivedate=March 10, 2014|df=}} During the previous year, Tectoy entered the gaming market for [[mobile device]]s. Branded as a subsidiary called Tec Toy Mobile, the company partnered with [[Level Up! Games]], responsible for games like the [[Massively multiplayer online role-playing game|MMORPG]] ''[[Ragnarok Online]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/folha/informatica/ult124u20299.shtml|title=Tec Toy investe no mercado de jogos para celular|last=|first=|date=July 3, 2006|website=Folha de S.Paulo|publisher=Grupo Folha|language=Portuguese|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=March 9, 2014}} The partnership between the two companies ended in the second half of 2010, when Tectoy sold its stake in Level Up!.{{cite web|url=http://institucional.tectoy.com.br/_arq/82_Arq10.pdf|title=Demonstrações financeiras 31/12/2010|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Tectoy|language=Portuguese|format=PDF|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6NxMG8pHu?url=http://www.tectoy.com.br/_arq/82_Arq10.pdf|archivedate=March [[Wi-Fi]].{{cite web|url=http://www.estadao.com.br/noticias/impresso,tectoy-tenta-se-recuperar-com-tv-digital,50253,0.htm|title=Tectoy tenta se recuperar com TV 18, 2014|deadurl=no|accessdate=February 28, 2013|df=}} In February 2009, Tectoy launched the first Blu-ray player manufactured in Brazil.{{cite web|url=http://tecnologia.terra.com.br/eletronicos/tectoy-lanca-tocador-de-blu-ray-fabricado-no-brasil,581853ba037ea310VgnCLD200000bbcceb0aRCRD.html|title=Tectoy lança tocador de Blu-ray fabricado no 10, 2014|deadurl=no|accessdate=February 28, 2014|df=}} Subsequently, neither the digital TV receiver nor the Blu-ray player have been financially successful.{{cite 11, 2014|df=}} [[Image:Zeebo-Real Console.jpg|200px|thumb|Tectoy partnered with Qualcomm to release the [[Zeebo]] in 2009|alt=]]Tectoy announced a partnership with [[Qualcomm]] in 2008 for a new 10, 2014|df=}} In turn, the Zeebo was not well received by consumers, selling only 30,000 units rather than the company's projection of 600,000. Fischer stated that Tectoy would be operating at a profit if it had not invested in and launched Zeebo.{{cite web|url=http://epocanegocios.globo.com/Revista/Common/0,,EMI254242-16642,00-A+TECTOY+PASSA+DE+FASE.html|title=A Tectoy passa de fase|last=Felitti|first=Guilherme|date=September 22, 2011|website=Época Negócios|publisher=Rede Globo|language=Portuguese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310054257/http://epocanegocios.globo.com/Revista/Common/0,,EMI254242-16642,00-A+TECTOY+PASSA+DE+FASE.html|archivedate=March 10, 2014|deadurl=no|accessdate=February 25, 2014|df=}} Faced with this scenario of losses, the Zeebo was discontinued in Brazil in 2011.{{cite web|url=http://g1.globo.com/tecnologia/noticia/2011/05/sem-emplacar-videogame-criado-no-brasil-deixa-de-ser-vendido-no-pais.html|title=Sem emplacar, videogame criado no Brasil deixa de ser vendido no país|last=|first=|date=May 31, 2011|website=Globo.com|publisher=Rede Globo|language=Portuguese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310053439/http://g1.globo.com/tecnologia/noticia/2011/05/sem-emplacar-videogame-criado-no-brasil-deixa-de-ser-vendido-no-pais.html|archivedate=March 10, 2014|deadurl=no|accessdate=March 9, 2014|df=}} The game purchase network, ZeeboNet, was shut down on September 30, 2011.{{cite web|accessdate=February 25, 2014|website=Universo Online|publisher=Grupo Folha|title=Zeebo Inc. confirma fim do console brasileiro|date=May 31, 2011|url=http://jogos.uol.com.br/ultimas-noticias/2011/05/31/zeebo-inc-fim-do-console-brasileiro.htm|language=Portuguese|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130817210849/http://jogos.uol.com.br/ultimas-noticias/2011/05/31/zeebo-inc-fim-do-console-brasileiro.htm|archivedate=August 17, 2013|df=}} === Further diversification and stock actions (2010-present) === For a short time starting in November 2010, Tectoy produced and marketed 14-inch tube TVs with 12 games included in memory. This production came at a time when LCD and plasma screen manufacturers accounted for 70% of production in the Free Economic Zone of Manaus.{{cite web|url=http://www.istoedinheiro.com.br/noticias/41584_A+TELINHA+DA+TECTOY|website=IstoÉ Dinheiro|first=Ralphe|last=Manzoni Jr|date=November 19, 2010|accessdate=February 28, 2014|title=A telinha da Tectoy|language=Portuguese|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310050702/http://www.istoedinheiro.com.br/noticias/41584_A+TELINHA+DA+TECTOY|archivedate=March 10, 2014|df=}} Faced with the success of outsourced [[set-top box]]es for the South Korean company Humax, which produced them for Sky, Tectoy executives saw the possibility of using the company's factory in Manaus for third-party products. This, the company reasoned, would be especially helpful to those who wanted to enter the Brazilian market without investing in their own structure. Tectoy's workforce rose from 200 to 400 employees as a result of the partnership with Humax,{{cite web|url=http://www.valor.com.br/arquivo/863743/tectoy-investe-em-producao-terceirizada|first=Moacir|last=Drska|website=Valor Econômico|date=December 20, 2010|accessdate=February 25, 2014|title=Tectoy investe em produção terceirizada|language=Portuguese|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140311122220/http://www.valor.com.br/arquivo/863743/tectoy-investe-em-producao-terceirizada|archivedate=March 11, 2014|df=}} which began on December 16, 2010. The company's partnership with Humax ended in the second quarter of 2013.{{cite web|accessdate=February 25, 2014|archivedate=February 26, 2014|url=http://institucional.tectoy.com.br/_arq/53_Arq10.pdf|publisher=Tec Toy S/A|format=PDF|date=September 30, 2013|title=ITR - Informações Trimestrais|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6NfAZ0Xlj?url=http://www.tectoy.com.br/_arq/53_Arq10.pdf|language=Portuguese|deadurl=yes|df=}} In the wake of higher revenues obtained in early 2011, Tectoy attempted to auction preferred and common shares. While the company expected to gain R$9.6 million from the sale, a lack of market interest prevented the sale from happening. Tectoy continued to invest in new categories and licensing in digital electronics. Tablets were a major part of the company's revenue in 2013, accounting for 37% of revenue between January and September, with the expectation of surpassing DVD players and becoming their main product category. In 2012, Tectoy licensed [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]] characters to launch a new product, the Magic Tablet.{{cite web|url=http://www.istoedinheiro.com.br/noticias/107304_INSISTO+LOGO+EXISTO|date=December 14, 2012|accessdate=February 25, 2014|title=Insisto, logo existo|website=IstoÉ Dinheiro|first=João|last=Varella|language=Portuguese|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310050659/http://www.istoedinheiro.com.br/noticias/107304_INSISTO+LOGO+EXISTO|archivedate=March 10, 2014|df=}} The company's shares were grouped in 2015. Tectoy was forced to carry out the procedure after actions of [[B3 (stock exchange)|BM&F Bovespa]] against [[penny stock]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.istoedinheiro.com.br/noticias/140325_BARRADOS+NO+BAILE|website=IstoÉ Dinheiro|title=Barrados no baile|first=Natália|last=Flach|date=February 21, 2014|accessdate=February 25, 2014|language=Portuguese|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140306220653/http://www.istoedinheiro.com.br/noticias/140325_BARRADOS+NO+BAILE|archivedate=March 6, 2014|df=}} A strategy of the company has been betting on [[nostalgia]] to bring back consoles that were sold in the 1980s and 1990s. In March 2017, Tectoy released the Atari Flashback 7, a version of the [[Atari 2600]], with 101 games in memory but without support to insert game cartridges.{{cite web|url=http://br.ign.com/atari-2600/46672/news/relancamento-do-atari-2600-chega-ao-brasil-nesta-quarta-feir|title=Relançamento do Atari 2600 chega ao Brasil nesta quarta-feira|last=Penilhas|first=Bruna|date=March 22, 2017|website=IGN Brasil|publisher=Ziff Davis|language=Portuguese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170418090537/http://br.ign.com/atari-2600/46672/news/relancamento-do-atari-2600-chega-ao-brasil-nesta-quarta-feir|archivedate=April 18, 2017|deadurl=no|accessdate=April 17, 2017|df=}} Additionally, by June of the same year, it was planned to relaunch the Mega Drive, with some additional features such as a [[Secure Digital|microSD Tectoy.|df=mdy-all}} ==Products== [[Image:Scompact.jpg|200px|thumb|Master System Super Compact, a Master System variant exclusively released by Tectoy in Brazil]] Tectoy is known for their handling and distribution of Sega consoles in Brazil. The company has sold all of Sega's consoles since 1987, including the Master System, Mega Drive, [[32X]], [[Sega CD]], Game Gear, Saturn, [[Sega Pico]], and Dreamcast, in addition to the ''Zillion'' laser tag gun. Because Tectoy continued to produce the Master System and Mega Drive years after its cancellation, the Master System is considered the longest-lived console in the [[History of video games|history of video game consoles]]. The company also introduced the [[Sega Meganet]] service to Brazil in 1995, starting with a focus on e-mail but later expanding to online multiplayer and chat by 1996, as well as partnering with Brazilian bank [[Banco Bradesco|Bradesco]] to develop a banking system, similar to Japan's connection with Nagoya Bank. As of 2015, the Master System and Mega Drive combined sell around 150,000 a year. This is a level comparable to modern consoles available in Brazil such as the [[PlayStation 4]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/brazil-is-a-video-game-alternate-universe-where-sega-beat-nintendo|title=Brazil Is An Alternate Video Game Universe Where Sega Beat Nintendo|last=Smith|first=Ernie|date=July 27, 2015|website=Atlas Obscura|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170621140933/http://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/brazil-is-a-video-game-alternate-universe-where-sega-beat-nintendo|archivedate=June 21, 2017|deadurl=no|accessdate=November 30, 2015|df=}} despite the Mega Drive being temporarily discontinued and reintroduced. Tectoy's hardware for the Master System and Mega Drive evolved over time into derivatives targeting the low-income market. These consoles generally do not have the cartridge slots, as games are installed directly on its internal memory. One of these consoles is the Mega Drive Portable, a portable Mega Drive with 20 games installed onto its memory.{{cite web|url=http://g1.globo.com/Noticias/Tecnologia/0,,MUL178351-6174,00-MEGA+DRIVE+VIRA+PORTATIL+COM+JOGOS.html|title=Mega Drive vira portátil com 20 jogos|last=|first=|date=November 12, 2007|website=Globo.com|publisher=Rede Globo|language=Portuguese|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090220185226/http://g1.globo.com/Noticias/Tecnologia/0,,MUL178351-6174,00-MEGA+DRIVE+VIRA+PORTATIL+COM+JOGOS.html|archive-date=2009-02-20|dead-url=no|access-date=|df=}} Other variations exclusive to Tectoy's releases include the Master System Super Compact, which is a wireless system that transmits to a television, and the Master System Girl, a version of the Super Compact in a neon pink case. In 2006, Tectoy released the Master System 3 Collection and the Mega Drive 3, including 120 and 71 built-in games, respectively. Tectoy has received and considered requests to remake the original Master System. [[Image:Master System Girl.jpg|200px|thumb|left|Master System Girl, a pink-colored variant of the Master System Super Compact]] In the 1990s, Tectoy translated several games published by Sega into Portuguese. Translated games include the first three ''[[Phantasy Star series|Phantasy Star]]'' games, ''[[Shining in the Darkness]]'', and ''[[Riven]]'', the last of which also incorporated [[Dubbing (filmmaking)|dubbed]] voices.{{cite web|url=http://www.techtudo.com.br/listas/noticia/2015/02/phantasy-star-shining-force-veja-os-melhores-jogos-de-rpg-para-mega-drive.html|title=Phantasy Star, Shining Force: veja os melhores jogos de RPG para Mega Drive|last=Coutinho|first=Dário|date=February 17, 2015|website=Techtudo|publisher=Globo Comunicação e Participações SA|language=Portuguese|access-date=February 26, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180622005123/http://www.techtudo.com.br/listas/noticia/2015/02/phantasy-star-shining-force-veja-os-melhores-jogos-de-rpg-para-mega-drive.html|archivedate=June 22, 2018|df=}} Additionally, Tectoy built relationships with other developers, including [[Capcom]], [[Acclaim Entertainment]], [[Electronic Arts]], and [[Midway Games]]. Tectoy would then translate titles from these developers into Portuguese for release in Brazil, and to tie in to popular Brazilian entertainment franchises. Some examples of this include: ''[[Teddy Boy (video game)|Teddy Boy]]'' became ''Geraldinho'', certain ''[[Wonder Boy]]'' titles became ''[[Monica's Gang]]'' games, and ''[[Ghost House (video game)|Ghost House]]'' became ''Chapolim vs. Dracula: Um Duelo Assutador'', based on Mexican TV series ''[[El Chapulín Colorado]]''. Additionally, Tectoy ported games for their Sega systems, such as ''[[Street Fighter II]]'' for the Master System and ''[[Duke Nukem 3D]]'' for the Mega Drive, as well as various games ported from the Game Gear to the more popular Master System. Aside from porting, the company developed ''[[Férias Frustradas do Pica-Pau]]'' after finding out that ''[[Woody Woodpecker]]'' was the most popular cartoon on Brazilian television. These titles were developed in-house by Tectoy in Brazil. Tectoy also suggested the development of ''[[Ayrton Senna's Super Monaco GP II]]'', a project that Sega accepted but would be the only suggestion from Tectoy that Sega approved. More recently, Tectoy created two Mega Drive games based on ''Show do Milhão'', a Brazilian game show based on the ''[[Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?]]'' format, and ''Mega Drive 4 Guitar Idol'', a 16-bit rhythm video game based on ''[[Guitar Hero]]'' with its own guitar peripheral. Tectoy had been granted a master license by Sega for all of their games, including those developed in Europe or America, and had permission to sell any game by Sega in Brazil. Aside from its work with Sega, Tectoy has developed and sold karaoke machines, set-top boxes, televisions pre-installed with games, mobile games, DVD players, Blu-ray players, a mobile TV receiver, the Nabaztag music player, and the Zeebo video game console. Tectoy also distributed [[Microsoft Windows|PC]] games in Brazil such as [[Blade Runner (1997 video game)|''Blade Runner'']], [[StarCraft (video game)|''StarCraft'']], and [[Daytona USA (video game)|''Daytona USA'']]. {{other uses}} {{EngvarB|date=January 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox film | name = The Falls | image = The Falls FilmPoster.jpeg | alt = | caption = | film name = | director = [[Peter Greenaway]] | producer = | writer = Peter Greenaway | screenplay = | story = | based on = <!-- {{based on|title of the original work|writer of the original work}} --> | starring = | narrator = | music = [[Michael Nyman]] | cinematography = | editing = | studio = | distributor = | released = 1980 | runtime = 185 min | country = United Kingdom | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''The Falls''''' is a 1980 film directed by [[Peter Greenaway]]. It was Greenaway's first feature-length film after many years making shorts. It does not have a traditional dramatic narrative; it takes the form of a [[mockumentary|mock documentary]] in 92 short parts.
==Plot== The world has been struck by a mysterious incident called the "Violent Unknown Event" or VUE, which has killed many people and left a great many survivors suffering from a common set of symptoms: mysterious ailments (some appearing to be mutations of evolving into a bird-like form), dreaming of water (categorised by form, such as Category 1, Flight, or Category 3, Waves) and becoming obsessed with birds and flight. Many of the survivors have been gifted with [[fictional language|new languages]]. They have also stopped aging, making them immortal (barring disease or injury).
A directory of these survivors has been compiled, and ''The Falls'' is presented as a film version of an excerpt from that directory, corresponding to the 92 entries for persons whose surnames begin with the letters FALL-. Not all of the 92 entries correspond to a person – some correspond to deleted entries, cross references and other oddities of the administrative process that has produced the directory. One biography concerns two people – the twin brothers Ipson and Pulat Fallari, who are played (in still photographs) by the [[Brothers Quay]].
In addition to the common VUE symptoms mentioned above, a number of themes run through the film. Among these are references to a number of bureaucratic organisations including the VUE Commission and the Bird Facilities Industries (a parody of the [[British Film Institute]] which produced the film), the [[List of years in aviation|history of manned flight]] from [[Daedalus]] with the suggestion that birds may be responsible for the VUE (and that the film may thus be seen as a sequel to Hitchcock's ''[[The Birds (film)|The Birds]]''), complex debates over the location of the epicentre of the VUE, and repeated references to [[Tulse Luper]]. Luper is a recurring off-stage character in Greenaway's early films, and would eventually appear on film in the epic series ''[[The Tulse Luper Suitcases]]'' (2003 onwards), which is itself named in ''The Falls''.
''The Falls'' includes clips of a number of Greenaway's early shorts. It also anticipates some of his later films: the subject of biography 27, Propine Fallax, is a pseudonym for Cissie Colpitts, the central figure of ''[[Drowning by Numbers]]'' (1988), while the car accident in biography 28 prefigures that in ''[[A Zed and Two Noughts]]'' (1985).
The largely formal and deadpan manner of the narration contrasts with the absurdity of the content.
==Characters== Two example biographies follow.
Bwythan Fallbutus is the 42nd victim of the Violent Unknown Event listed in the VUE directory. Bwythan Fallbutus was Betheda Fallbutus' eldest son. He was the officially-appointed VUE Commission's linguistic expert. He lived just off the Goldhawk Road within a three-minute walking distance of his mother, whom he visited every day. The VUE had given Bwythan a bone-marrow deficiency, wattles and cobs along his backbone, and a foot disease that shredded his toe-nails. He could drink salt water without harm but felt listless and debilitated away from the influence of [[chlorophyll]], which is why there were always several plantpots in his office, and even on his desk. Bwythan could speak fourteen VUE languages and interpret successfully in nine of them at a diplomatic level. It was Bwythan who had organised the examination of Agropio Fallaver, the sole speaker of the language named after him. Although Bwythan had come to the private opinion that Fallaver was somehow a fake manoeuvred by FOX, the Society for Ornithological Extermination. Bwythan has privately researched the ten-thousand most popularly used words in forty-three of the main VUE languages and has produced a comparative dictionary. From this research he wrote a book, ''View from [[Babylon|Babel]], to explain, or attempt to explain the gift of tongues and the fragmentation of language''. In trying to do this, and in his associated search for a common linguistic denominator, he successfully demonstrated that the names of birds were important key words. It was rumoured that it was because of the conclusions of his research that Bwythan was run down by a white van, registration number NID 92, on a zebra crossing in the [[Goldhawk Road tube station|Goldhawk Road]]. A van with the same registration had been seen outside Bwythan's house an hour before the accident. The police later found the vehicle responsible on a deserted airfield. It was supposed that the assailant, or assailants, had escaped by air.
Catch-Hanger Fallcaster is one of the victims of the Violent Unknown Event listed in the VUE directory. Her biography, number 49 in the movie, is one amidst several interrelated biographies concerning different members of the Fallcaster family. Catch-Hanger Fallcaster had been a teacher. She had taught Russian to [[Germany|Germans]]. And certainly before the VUE, she would never have admitted to a great knowledge of [[ornithology]]. The VUE had made Catch-Hanger three inches taller, paralysed her index fingers and improved her eyesight. She now taught Abcadefghan to anyone who wanted to learn. Catch-Hanger has translated [[Tulse Luper]]'s ''Some Birds of the Northern Hemisphere'', establishing a definitive pronunciation of the Abcadefghan equivalents for the [[Falconidae]]. She has also started work on an Abcadefghan-English language primer that is based substantially on the three [[children's song|nursery rhymes]], "Goosey, Goosey, Gander," "Who Killed Cock-Robin?," and "I Shot a Little Duck."
==Soundtrack== The soundtrack is mainly by [[Michael Nyman]] and is partly based, like his later music for ''Drowning by Numbers'', on the slow movement of [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]]'s ''[[Sinfonia Concertante for Violin, Viola and Orchestra K. 364]]''. It also includes numerous clips from various songs popular among the avant-garde of the time, including pieces by [[Brian Eno]] (in particular "Golden Hours" from [[Another Green World]]) and snippets of "Jugband Blues", the last song [[Syd Barrett]] recorded with [[Pink Floyd]].
==Languages== [[fictional language|Languages]] the survivors have been gifted with include:
*Abcadefghan **Abcadefghan is often used in the preparation of papers on engineering, [[metallurgy]] and radiophonics. It is suggested that [[Sami people|Sami]] and [[Finnish people|Finns]] can understand Abcadefghan, which would make Abcadefghan a [[Finno-Samic languages|Finno-Samic language]] but, in itself, is not that scientifically valuable since there aren't that many technical-papers in these languages. Research is required to determine the extent to which Abcadefghan is derived from or related to [[Abecedarian]]. (Curiously enough, Abecedarian is never mentioned as a VUE language in the movie). In the movie story, the language is taught by Catch-Hanger Fallcaster to ''"anyone who wanted to learn".'' She is said to have translated [[Tulse Luper]]'s ''Some Birds of the Northern Hemisphere'' into Abcadefghan. The name of the language, taking the first ordered letters of the alphabet as its root, seems to have been logically inspired by its technical, industrial nature. In fact, the language actually spoken here is [[Estonian language|Estonian]]. *Agalese *Agreet *Allow *Allow-ease *Althuese *Antoneen *Betelguese *Candoese *Capistan *Carn-est-aero *Cathaganian *Cathanay *Curdine *Entree *Fallaver **Fallaver is the ninety-second language originated by the VUE. Fallaver began and ended with its only speaker, Agropio Fallaver, who was suggested to be an unsuspecting vehicle for FOX, the Society for Ornithological Extermination. It was Bwythan Fallbutus who conducted the investigation about Agropio Fallaver and his unique language, and had come to the conclusion that Agropio was a fake manoeuvred by FOX. See also the word ''palaver''. *Foreignester *Glendower *Glozel *Hapaxlegomena **(a reference to [[Hapax legomenon]]) *Hartileas B. *Instantaneious Dekis *Ipostan *Itino Re *Karnash *Kantan *Katan *Kath-a-ganian *Maudine *Mickel-ease *O-Lev-Lit **(Possibly a reference to the [[General Certificate of Education|O-level school exam]]) *Os-leet-ter *Orthocathalian *Regest *Sackamayer *U-thalian *Untowards *Vionester

'''''The Last Warning''''' is a 1928 American [[Mystery fiction|mystery film]] directed by [[Paul Leni]], and starring [[Laura La Plante]], [[Montagu Love]], and [[Margaret Livingston]]. Its plot follows a New York producer's attempt to re-stage a play five years after one of the original cast members was murdered in the theater. The film is based on the 1922 [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] [[melodrama]] of the same name by Thomas F. Fallon, which in turn was based on the story ''House of Fear'' by Wadsworth Camp, the father of the writer [[Madeleine L'Engle]].
Conceived as a followup to Leni's wildly successful 1927 production ''[[The Cat and the Canary (1927 film)|The Cat and the Canary]]'' (also starring La Plante), the film was produced by [[Universal Pictures]] under [[Carl Laemmle]]. Principal photography took place in Los Angeles in the summer of 1928 on sets recycled from Univeral's ''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1925 film)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'' (1925). It premiered on [[Christmas Day]] 1928 before expanding in January 1929, and was released as both a part-[[sound film|sound]] as well as a [[silent film]]; the silent version is the only known extant version.{{sfn|McCaffrey| 1999|p=172}} It was the final film directed by Leni before his death from [[blood poisoning]] on September 2, 1929.<ref name = "Atkinson"/>
Response by critics to ''The Last Warning'' varied, with many praising its performances and cinematography, though several commented on its incoherent plot, and others criticized its integration of sound, feeling it presented optimally as a silent film. In 2016, Universal Pictures selected the film for [[Film preservation|restoration]], using elements from two different prints owned by the [[Packard Humanities Institute]] and the [[Cinémathèque Française]].
==Plot== [[File:The Last Warning (1929).ogg|thumb|left|thumbtime=14:59|upright=1|''The Last Warning'']] In a [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] production of a play entitled ''The Snare'', one of the actors, John Woodford, inexplicably dies during a stage performance, and his body disappears. Few clues exist as to what caused his death, aside from several drops of liquid found that resembled [[chloroform]]. Rumors of a [[love triangle]] between Woodford and two cast members circulate as a possible motive for his death.
Five years after the theater's closure, producer Mike Brody decides to solve the mystery by again staging the play with the remaining cast and re-enacting Woodford's murder. During rehearsals in the abandoned theater, strange occurrences plague the cast, including ominous noises, falling scenery, and an unexplained fire. Doris, the lead actress, has her purse stolen from her dressing room by an unseen assailant; Josiah Bunce, the [[Stage management|stage manager]], reportedly receives a telegram warning him to drop out of the play, signed by John Woodford, and the theater's new owner, Arthur McHugh, also receives a visit from Woodford's ghost.
The production continues, and during the final rehearsal, Harvey Carleton inexplicably disappears from the stage during a blackout. Doris spots a mysterious masked figure in a theater box in addition to a man resembling John Woodford, but both disappear. Behind a picture hanging on the stage, a lever is discovered which opens a trap door, where the cast find Harvey incoherent. Arthur and Richard Quayle, another cast member, venture inside, where they discover a tunnel that leads to Doris's dressing room.
Arthur has police officers appointed at the theater for the show's opening the following night. During the performance, an electrical wire charged to 400 volts is discovered connected to a [[candlestick]] onstage, and Arthur lunges at Richard to prevent him from touching it during the final scene. The unseen masked assailant is discovered hiding inside a [[grandfather clock]] onstage, but he drops through a trap door in the floor just after shooting one of the police officers. The assailant scales the theater and throws a [[Mannequin|dummy]] resembling John Woodford onto the stage. He then begins swinging from a rope, but is brought back down by a stagehand who cuts it.
The masked assailant is discovered to be Josiah, who caused Woodford's death via [[electrocution]] and had been behind the "hauntings" to prevent the theater from being used.
==Cast== {{cast listing| * [[Laura La Plante]] as Doris Terry * [[Montagu Love]] as Arthur McHugh * [[Roy D'Arcy]] as Harvey Carleton * [[Margaret Livingston]] as Evalynda Hendon * [[John Boles (actor)|John Boles]] as Richard Quayle * [[Burr McIntosh]] as Josiah Bunce * [[Mack Swain]] as Robert * [[Bert Roach]] as Mike Brody * [[Carrie Daumery]] as Barbara Morgan * [[Slim Summerville]] as Tommy Wall * Francisco Maran as Jeffries * Bud Phelps as Sammy * [[Torben Meyer]] as Gene * [[Charles K. French]] as Doctor * [[D'Arcy Corrigan]] as John Woodford * [[Harry Northrup]] as Coroner }} ==Production== ===Screenplay and filming=== The film was envisioned as a companion piece to director Leni's earlier ''[[The Cat and the Canary (1927 film)|The Cat and the Canary]]'', due to that film's great popularity. Universal assigned Leni to the project under the assumption that his previous success would yield significant box-office results.{{sfn|Soister|Nicolella|Joyce|2014|p=311}} It is based on the 1922 play of the same name by Thomas F. Fallon,{{sfn|Conrich|2004|p=47}} which ran for 238 performances from October 24, 1922, until May 1923 at the [[Klaw Theatre]].<ref>{{cite web|work=[[Playbill]]|title=''The Last Warning'' at the Klaw Theatre|url=http://www.playbill.com/production/the-last-warning-klaw-theatre-vault-0000006318|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181120011532/http://www.playbill.com/production/the-last-warning-klaw-theatre-vault-0000006318|archive-date=November 20, 2018|publisher=TotalTheater|issn=0551-0678}}</ref> Fallon's play was in turn based on the story ''House of Fear'' by Wadsworth Camp, the father of writer [[Madeleine L'Engle]].<ref>{{cite web|work=[[The Washington Post]]|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/09/07/AR2007090702690.html?noredirect=on|title=Writer Madeleine L'Engle, 88; Author of 'A Wrinkle in Time'|date=September 8, 2007|last=Bernstein|first=Adam|archive-url=http://archive.is/OxrGU|archive-date=November 20, 2018}}</ref>
[[Principal photography]] began in August 1928.{{sfn|Soister|2001|p=18}} The theater set used in the film had originally been used in the 1925 ''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1925 film)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'' starring Lon Chaney,<ref name = "Atkinson">{{cite web| url =http://www.silentfilm.org/eventinfo/the-last-warning-festival-2016 | title = The Last Warning | last = Atkinson | first =Michael | website = SilentFilm.org| publisher=San Francisco Silent Film Festival| dead-url=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161117063419/http://www.silentfilm.org/eventinfo/the-last-warning-festival-2016|archive-date=November 17, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|work=[[New York Daily News]]|last=Shaffer|first=George|location=New York City|title='Phantom of Opera' Sets Dug Up for New Spook Film|date=June 26, 1928|p=30|via=Newspapers.com|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25545116/daily_news/}} {{open access}}</ref> and was located in [[Universal City, California]].{{sfn|Conrich|2004|p=44}}
===Casting=== Actress Laura La Plante, a former-teenage actress who had previously starred in Leni's ''The Cat and the Canary'', was given top-billing in her role as Doris Terry, though her part in the film is considerably less involved than in the former.{{sfn|Soister|2001|p=29}} Film historian John Soister characterizes La Plante's role as that of an [[ingénue]],{{sfn|Soister|2001|p=20}} consisting primarily of reactions to "assorted assaults, visions, and set-ups."{{sfn|Soister|2001|p=29}} The film marked La Plante's first talking picture.<ref name=hartford/> British actor Montagu Love was cast opposite La Plante, receiving second-billing. Soister notes that Love was "cast against type" for his role, that of "no-nonsense" theater owner Arthur McHugh.{{sfn|Soister|2001|p=29}}
Margaret Livingston, an actress who had also begun her career as a teenager, was cast in the role of actress Evalynda Hendon; her performance in the film helped earn her a role in Universal's ''The Charlatan'', released later that year.{{sfn|Soister|2001|p=30}} In the role of Richard Quayle, Leni cast actor [[John Boles (actor)|John Boles]], who subsequently had a minor part in ''[[Frankenstein (1931 film)|Frankenstein]]'' (1931).{{sfn|Soister|2001|p=32}} [[Bert Roach]] was cast as Mike Brody, the producer who re-stages the play in the film.{{sfn|Soister|2001|p=32}} Barbara, an elderly [[character actor|character actress]] who starred in the original play in which Woodford was murdered, is portrayed by [[Netherlands|Dutch]] actress Carrie Daumery.{{sfn|Soister|2001|p=22}} This was Daumery's only film credit from the silent era, and her role is likened by Soister and others to that of Flora Finch in ''The Cat and the Canary'', but stripped of any comedic tone.{{sfn|Soister|Nicolella|Joyce|2014|p=312}}
==Release== According to the [[American Film Institute]],<ref name=AFI/> ''The Last Warning'' had its theatrical debut in New York City on January 6, 1929.{{sfn|Soister|2001|p=33}} However, special advance screenings occurred on [[Christmas Day]] 1928 in several U.S. cities, including [[Chillicothe, Missouri]],<ref name=christmas>{{cite news|work=[[Chillicothe Constitution-Tribune]]|location=Chillicothe, Missouri|title=The Last Warning|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25542418/the_chillicothe_constitutiontribune/|via=Newspapers.com|p=3|date=December 18, 1928}} {{open access}}</ref> and [[Manhattan, Kansas]].<ref>{{cite news|work=[[The Manhattan Mercury]]|location=Manhattan, Kansas|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25542745/the_manhattan_mercury/|via=Newspapers.com|title=Wareham Theater Program|date=December 17, 1928|p=2|quote="Christmas Special: "The Last Warning" with Laura La Plante}} {{open access}}</ref>
The film was marketed as a successor to producer Leni's previous film ''The Cat and the Canary'', attributed to producer Laemmle's "discriminating supervision."<ref>{{cite news|work=[[Detroit Free Press]]|location=Detroit, Michigan|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25542547/detroit_free_press/|title=Carl Laemmle, Jr., Earns Signal Promotion For One of his Years|via=Newspapers.com|date=December 23, 1928|p=43}} {{open access}}</ref> It is often considered one of the last [[Silent film|silent films]] produced by [[Universal Studios]], but it was also released in a "part-talkie" [[Movietone sound system|Movietone]] version with a brief minute or two of [[Sound film|synch-sound]] footage added, as well as screams, cries, and other sound effects.{{sfn|Soister|2001|p=18}}<ref>{{cite news|work=[[The Register-Guard]]|location=Eugene, Oregon|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25545228/the_eugene_guard/|p=5|date=January 5, 1929|via=Newspapers.com|title=Association Show Booked; 'Last Warning' Coming}} {{open access}}</ref> These scenes have since been lost.<ref name = "Atkinson"/> Few prints of the film exist in the United States: One is owned by the [[George Eastman House Motion Picture Collection]] in [[Rochester, New York]], which was originally owned by the [[Cinémathèque Française]], and is slightly edited and entirely silent with [[French language|French]] intertitles.{{sfn|Soister|2001|p=18}}
===Restoration=== In 2016, the film underwent [[Digital photograph restoration|digital]] [[Film preservation|restoration]] by Universal Pictures, sourced from both the Cinémathèque Française print, as well as a print featuring the original English title cards owned by the [[Packard Humanities Institute]] Collection of the [[UCLA Film & Television Archive]].<ref name=PR/> The restored print was screened at the [[Castro Theatre]] as part of the [[San Francisco Silent Film Festival]] on June 4, 2016.<ref name=PR>{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/universal-pictures-restores-silent-film-the-last-warning-honoring-the-studios-rich-history-and-cultural-legacy-300278957.html|work=[[PR Newswire]]|title=Universal Pictures restores silent film, The Last Warning, Honoring the Studio's rich history and cultural legacy|date=June 3, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160716205229/http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/universal-pictures-restores-silent-film-the-last-warning-honoring-the-studios-rich-history-and-cultural-legacy-300278957.html|archive-date=July 16, 2016}}</ref> It was again screened in September 2016 at Cinecon Classic Film Festival in Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite web|work=[[UCLA Film & Television Archive]]|publisher=[[University of California, Los Angeles]]|url=https://www.cinema.ucla.edu/blogs/archival-spaces/2016/09/30/cinecon-52|date=September 30, 2016|title=Cinecon 52|last=Horak|first=Jan-Christopher|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181120020707/https://www.cinema.ucla.edu/blogs/archival-spaces/2016/09/30/cinecon-52|archive-date=November 20, 2018}}</ref>
==Critical response== ===Contemporaneous=== Though it re-teamed Leni with ''The Cat and the Canary'' star Laura La Plante and features a similar style, ''The Last Warning'' lacks the supernatural elements of ''The Cat and the Canary'' and is therefore usually considered in the [[Mystery fiction|mystery]] genre rather than the [[Horror film|horror]] genre<ref name = "Atkinson"/>; some historians, however, have classed it as a horror film.{{sfn|Soister|2001|p=20}} Elements of comedy present in Leni's ''The Cat and the Canary'' are also absent from the film.{{sfn|Petrie|2002|p=189}} Extant published reviews of the film were varied.{{sfn|Soister|2001|p=32}}{{sfn|Petrie|2002|p=189}}
Mordaunt Hall of ''[[The New York Times]]'' noted the film contained "some finely directed passages," but that it was "not especially disturbing."<ref name=hall>{{cite news|last=Hall|first=Mordaunt|title=THE SCREEN; A Nonchalant Sleuth. Who Is the Killer? Giddy Comedy. The Noble Count|location=New York City|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 7, 1929|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9B07E7D61031E33ABC4F53DFB7668382639EDE}}</ref> Martin Dickstein of the ''[[Brooklyn Eagle|Brooklyn Daily Eagle]]'' described the film as being "related with such vagueness that the picture fail[s] to hold together," but praised Leni's "propitious use of "the camera angle," and it is through this inventive maneuvering of the lens that the picture achieves at least a visual significance."<ref>{{cite news|last=Dickstein|first=Martin|p=E-3|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25544974/the_brooklyn_daily_eagle/|title=Slow Motion|work=[[Brooklyn Eagle|Brooklyn Daily Eagle]]|location=Brooklyn, New York|date=January 13, 1929|via=Newspapers.com}} {{open access}}</ref> A critic of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' similarly found the cinematography "highly interesting" and the plot "lost in a maze of double and triple exposures," adding that there "is a decided lack of spontaneity in the sound sequences."<ref>{{cite news|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|title="Last Warning" A Pantages Feature|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25545348/the_los_angeles_times/|date=January 8, 1929|via=Newspapers.com|location=Los Angeles, California|p=11}} {{open access}}</ref>
The majority of the criticism surrounding the film had to do with its integration of sound.{{sfn|Petrie|2002|p=189}} Irene Thirer of the ''[[New York Daily News]]'', who felt the film "should never have been a talkie," elaborating that the dialogue episodes "retard the action" and "are not well done."<ref name=thirer>{{cite news|work=[[New York Daily News]]|location=New York City|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25541536/daily_news/|title="The Last Warning" Fine Mystery Stuff|date=January 6, 1929|via=Newspapers.com|last=Thirer|first=Irene}} {{open access}}</ref> ''[[The Montana Standard]]'' noted that the film "presents many thrills" and was widely enjoyed by the audiences at the film's premiere in [[Butte, Montana|Butte]].<ref>{{cite news|work=[[The Montana Standard]]|title=Audience Enjoys Mystery Picture|location=Butte, Montana|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25542055/the_montana_standard/|via=Newspapers.com|date=December 15, 1929}} {{open access}}</ref> A critic of the ''[[Hartford Courant]]'' alternately felt that, "as a talking picture, the film retains all the chill values of the play, with its eerie noises, screams, fright-fraught dialogue and general noise and excitement," but conceded that "it decidedly is not the scary kind of mystery play that the average person would find too startling."<ref name=hartford>{{cite news|work=[[Hartford Courant]]|location=Hartford, Connecticut|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25542256/hartford_courant/|title=Stage and Screen|date=January 24, 1929|p=13|via=Newspapers.com}} {{open access}}</ref> Sid Silverman, writing for ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', noted the use of sound effects as "multiple, continuous, and in detail," and that the film included "enough screams to stimulate the average film mob into sticking through it."<ref>{{cite news|last=Silverman|first=Sid|title=The Last Warning|page=44|date= January 9, 1929|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]}}</ref> Hall also criticized the film's utilization of sound, writing: "There are too many outbursts of shrieking, merely to prove the effect of the audible screen, to cause any spine-chilling among those watching this production."<ref name=hall/>
The ''[[Chillicothe Constitution-Tribune]]'' noted that ''The Last Warning'' "the most thrilling mystery film released this season,"<ref>{{cite news|work=[[Chillicothe Constitution-Tribune]]|location=Chillicothe, Missouri|date=February 23, 1929|p=4|title="The Last Warning" A Chilling Mystery Thriller|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25541911/the_chillicothe_constitutiontribune/|via=Newspapers.com}} {{open access}}</ref> while the ''[[Billings Gazette]]'' deemed it "the greatest mystery picture ever filmed."<ref>{{cite news|work=[[Billings Gazette]]|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25542178/the_billings_gazette/|via=Newspapers.com|location=Billings, Montana|title=Fannie Brice in "My Man"|date=March 17, 1929|p=7}} {{open access}}</ref> ''[[Photoplay]]'' was less laudatory, noting: "This could have been a gorgeous mystery story, but it's an obvious cross between ''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1925 film)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'' and ''[[The Terror (1928 film)|The Terror]]'', with none of their consistency or power."<ref>{{cite magazine|work=[[Photoplay]]|title=The Last Warning – Universal|p=76|date=February 1929|url=https://archive.org/details/photoplay3536movi/page/n207|issn=0732-538X|publisher=[[Macfadden Communications Group|Macfadden Publications]]}}</ref>
===Retrospective=== In a retrospective assessment, author and film critic [[Leonard Maltin]] awarded the film two and a half out of four stars, commending its camerawork and direction, but criticizing the film's story as "silly."{{sfn|Maltin|Green|Edelman|2010|p=365}} Commenting on the finale, film historian [[Graham Petrie]] notes that Leni and cinematographer [[Hal Mohr]] "handle the camera with the utmost possible freedom, culminating in a scene in which the camera swings on a rope with the villian from one part of the theater to another. Along the way, Leni revels in the shadows, cobwebs, [[Dutch angle|tilted angles]], subtly distorted perspectives, ominously confined spaces, and clutching hands that had by now become his trademark."{{sfn|Petrie|2002|p=215}} Petrie, who classifies the film as a [[thriller film|thriller]] rather than a mystery, emphasizes that its stylistic and visual elements supersede narrative plausibility and characterization.{{sfn|Petrie|2002|pages=215–216}}
==Other adaptations== ''The Last Warning'' was re-made in 1939 by [[Joe May]] under the title ''[[The House of Fear (1939 film)|The House of Fear]]''.<ref name=AMG>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmovie.com/movie/v126307 |title=The House of Fear (1939) |website=[[AllMovie]] |publisher=AllRovie| archive-url=http://archive.is/2wpz|archive-date=July 17, 2012}}</ref>
