{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox non-profit | name = Society of MICE | image = Mice Crest.jpg | image_size = 200px | type = | founded_date = 1961 | tax_id = | registration_id = | founder = | location = [[Kingston upon Hull]], United Kingdom | coordinates = | origins = | key_people = | area_served = [[Kingston upon Hull]], United Kingdom | product = Fundraising | mission = Fellowship, benevolence, charity | focus = | method = Entertainment | revenue = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | title= | num_members = | subsid = | owner = | non-profit_slogan = | former name = | homepage ={{url|1=http://beehive.thisishull.co.uk/default.asp?WCI=SiteHome&ID=4803}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''The Society of M.I.C.E.''' is a charitable organisation based in [[Kingston upon Hull]]. It was founded in 1961, by a group of dedicated [[entertainment|entertainers]] working on an idea proposed by Al Gillyon. The society is modelled on the [[Grand Order of Water Rats]]. Its membership is exclusively of men, although the members wives, partners and friends often help out in varying capacities. MICE is an [[acronym]] for '''"Men in Charitable Endeavour"'''. ==The beginning== In 1960, Al Gillyon proposed the setting up of an organisation in Kingston upon Hull similar to the Grand Order of Water Rats. The idea was talked about in clubs, at shows, even in people's front rooms after a show. But, in the words of Al Gillyon, "We cannot hold a first meeting until permission has been obtained from the Variety Artist Association" of which all were loyal members. Permission of the association was granted and the first ever meeting To which hirteen entertainers were invited, was held at the Windmill Hotel, Witham, Kingston upon Hull on 13 February 1961. Ten were able to attend. Officers were elected, it was agreed that the aims of the group, '''''[[Fellow]]ship''''', '''''Benevolence''''' and '''''[[Charity (virtue)|Charity]]''''' should be paramount and the group should be known as "The Society of MICE". ===The Offices of the Society=== [[Image:Terry Matsell 1.jpg|thumb|175px|Terry Matsell, one of the founder members, and the first SCRIBE MOUSE]] The Society has the usual [[committee]] structure, with a President and Vice-president elected annually, chosen singly by the outgoing President and announced at the annual dinner, which is held in Mid February. There are also positions for chairman, Secretary, Treasurer and the Steward to the [[Elder (administrative title)|Elders]]. The only difference is the title of these positions, all of which are extremely fitting:- *President = '''KING MOUSE''' *Vice-President = '''PRINCE MOUSE''' *Chairman = '''TRAP GUARD''' *Secretary = '''SCRIBE MOUSE''' *Treasurer = '''KEEPER OF THE CHEESE''' *Steward to the Elders = '''PILOT MOUSE''' There are other positions within the society, including the '''CONCERT MOUSE''', who organises the concerts. ===Founder Members=== The following: *Al Gillyon *Harry Hemingway *Clive Hunter *Terry Matsell *Jimmy Welsh *Jack Wilkinson *Brian Winchester are considered to be the founder members of the society as they were either present at the very first meeting of the society, or offered their apologies for absence. From these members, the first KING MOUSE was Al Gillyon, the first PRINCE MOUSE was Jack Wilkinson, the first SCRIBE MOUSE was Terry Matsell, and the first TRAP GUARD was Jimmy Welsh, who at the time was also the Vice-Chairman of the Variety Artists Association. ==Today== The Society is currently made up of Singers & [[Entertainment|Entertainers]], mainly from the [[Kingston upon Hull]] area, along with many other members who perform equally as important roles behind the scenes. Members of the 'Old Flames' (Retired members of [[Humberside]] fire brigade) have also joined the society" and [[Stars in Their Eyes]]" champion [[Ian Moor]] is a member and former holder of the office of Prince Mouse. The Society's aim is to raise funds for local good causes and charities, by means of live concert shows and other fund raising events. The society holds [[raffle|tombola]] & [[raffle]] stalls at various outdoor events throughout the summer and concerts are usually twice monthly in and around the [[Kingston upon Hull]] area. Venues vary from clubs to residential homes. It holds meetings every fortnight, to discuss future concerts and other matters regarding fund raising for the community. The meeting venue has changed several times over the years, and is referred to by members as the '''MOUSE HOLE'''. [[Image:Mice Singers1.jpg|right|thumb|250px|The MICE Singers]] ===The MICE Singers=== In 1996, the society added an extra act to the concerts, in the form of a [[choir]], made up of several of the society's members. Initially called "The Bolder Boys", named after Harry Bolder, who conducted the choir in its early years and whose idea it was to form the choir, today it is known as "The MICE Singers". As well as regular appearances at the society's concerts, they perform at many other venues, and are now in great demand throughout the year, with appearances at [[weddings]], residential homes, [[harvest festival]]s, [[schools]], and other events. ===Anthem=== The Society has an anthem, with [[lyrics]] written by one of the founder members, Clive Hunter, who adapted the words to the tune of [[Three Blind Mice]]. The anthem is sung at all concerts, and at the annual dinner by all the members present. ===The King's Special Project=== Each year the elected King Mouse nominates a charity or organisation to be the prime beneficiary of the years fundraising efforts and specific concerts and events are chosen to raise funds solely for this purpose. A [[cheque]] for the grand total raised is then presented to a representative from the charity or organisation at the annual "Special Presentation Evening", which is held at the end of January, shortly before the annual dinner. ==Former King & Prince Mouse== [[Image:MICEPrince&King2007d.jpg|thumb|250px|The 2007 King & Prince Mouse

{{Other uses|Tivoli (disambiguation){{!}}Tivoli}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox amusement park | name = Tivoli Gardens | image = [[File:Entrancetotivoli.jpg|220px]] | caption = The entrance to Tivoli, illuminated at night | resort = | location = [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]] | location2 = | location3 = | coordinates = {{Coord|55|40|25|N|12|34|06|E|type:landmark_region:DK-101|display=it}} | theme = | homepage = [http://tivoli.dk Tivoli.dk] | owner = Tivoli A/S | general_manager = Lars Liebst | operator = Tivoli A/S | rides = 25 | coasters = 4 | water_rides = 2 | opening_date = {{Start date and years ago|df=yes|1843|08|15}} | closing_date = <!-- {{End date|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | previous_names = | season = | visitors = 4,6 million in 2016<ref name="tivoligardens.com">http://www.tivoligardens.com/en/om/virksomheden/aarsrapporter/2016</ref> }}
'''Tivoli Gardens''' (or simply '''Tivoli''') is an [[amusement park]] and [[pleasure garden]] in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]. The park opened on 15 August 1843 and is the second-oldest operating amusement park in the world,<ref>{{cite web|title=Top attractions in Denmark|url=http://www.visitdenmark.com/guide/denmarks-most-visited-attractions|website=visitdenmark.com|publisher=Visit Denmark|accessdate=8 April 2016}}</ref> after [[Dyrehavsbakken]] in nearby [[Klampenborg]], also in Denmark.
With 4.6 million visitors in 2017,<ref name="tivoligardens.com"/> Tivoli is the second-most popular seasonal amusement park in the world after [[Europa-Park]]. Tivoli is the most-visited theme park in [[Scandinavia]], and the fifth most-visited theme park in Europe, only behind [[Disneyland Park (Paris)|Disneyland Park]], [[Europa-Park]], [[Walt Disney Studios Park]] and [[Efteling]].
==History== {{refimprove section|date=August 2012}} The amusement park was first called "Tivoli & Vauxhall";<ref name="copenhagenet1">[http://www.copenhagenet.dk/cph-map/cph-tivoli.asp Tivoli – Tivoli Gardens Copenhagen – Copenhagen Portal – Tourist Guide]. Copenhagenet.dk. Retrieved on 15 August 2011.</ref> "Tivoli" alluding to the [[Jardin de Tivoli, Paris|Jardin de Tivoli]] in Paris (which in its turn had been named from [[Tivoli, Italy|Tivoli]] near [[Rome]], [[Italy]]),"Vauxhall" alluding to the [[Vauxhall Gardens]] in London. It is also mentioned in various books, like ''Number the Stars'' by Lois Lowry.
Tivoli's founder, [[Georg Carstensen]] (b. 1812 – d. 1857), obtained a five-year charter to create Tivoli by telling [[King Christian VIII]] that "when the people are amusing themselves, they do not think about politics". The monarch granted Carstensen use of roughly 15 acres (61,000 m²) of the fortified [[glacis]] outside Vesterport (the West Gate) for an annual rent. Therefore, until the 1850s, Tivoli was outside the city, accessible through Vesterport.
From the very start, Tivoli included a variety of attractions: buildings in the exotic style of an imaginary Orient: a theatre, band stands, restaurants and cafés, flower gardens, and mechanical [[amusement ride]]s such as a [[merry-go-round]] and a primitive [[Roller_coaster#Scenic_railways|scenic railway]]. After dark, colored lamps illuminated the gardens. On certain evenings, specially designed [[fireworks]] could be seen reflected in Tivoli's lake.
Composer [[Hans Christian Lumbye]] (b. 1810 – d. 1874) was Tivoli's musical director from 1843 to 1872. Lumbye was inspired by Viennese waltz composers like the Strauss family ([[Johann Strauss I]] and his sons), and became known as the "Strauss of the North." Many of his compositions are specifically inspired by the gardens, including "Salute to the Ticket Holders of Tivoli", "Carnival Joys" and "A Festive Night at Tivoli". The [[Copenhagen Philharmonic Orchestra|Tivoli Symphony Orchestra]] still performs many of his works.
[[File:The Tivoli park, Copenhagen, Denmark.jpg|thumb|upright=1.4|Tivoli's pirate ship, {{circa|1900}}]]
Tivoli was also used predominantly in the 1961 science fiction film, Reptilicus.
In 1874, Chinese style Pantomimeteatret (The Pantomime Theatre) took the place of an older smaller theatre. The audience stands in the open, the stage being inside the building. The theatre's "curtain" is a mechanical peacock's tail. From the very beginning, the theatre was the home of Italian pantomimes, introduced in Denmark by the Italian [[Giuseppe Casorti]]. This tradition, which is dependent on the Italian [[Commedia dell'Arte]] has been kept alive, including the characters Cassander (the old father), Columbine (his beautiful daughter), [[Harlequin]] (her lover), and, especially popular with the youngest spectators, the stupid servant [[Pierrot]]. The absence of spoken dialogue is an advantage, as Tivoli is now an international tourist attraction.
In the late 19th and early 20th century, Tivoli also hosted [[Human zoo|human exhibitions]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=Human Exhibitions. Race, Gender and Sexuality in Ethnic Displays|last=Andreassen|first=Rikke|publisher=Ashgate|year=2015|isbn=9781472422453|location=Farnham|pages=13-15|quote=|via=}}</ref>
In 1943, [[Nazism|Nazi]] sympathisers burnt many of Tivoli's buildings, including the concert hall, to the ground. Temporary buildings were constructed in their place and the park was back in operation after a few weeks.<ref>The Twentieth Century with Walter Cronkite: Sabotage. CBS, 1950s.</ref>
Tivoli is always evolving without abandoning its original charm or traditions. As Georg Carstensen said in 1844, "Tivoli will never, so to speak, be finished," a sentiment echoed just over a century later when [[Walt Disney]] said of his own Tivoli-inspired [[theme park]], "[[Disneyland Park (Anaheim)|Disneyland]] will never be completed. It will continue to grow as long as there is imagination left in the world." In Icelandic, Danish, Norwegian and Swedish, the word tivoli has become synonymous with any amusement park.
==Rides== [[File:Tivoligardens2.jpg|thumb|upright=1.4|Dragon Boat lake and ''[[Dæmonen]]'' roller coaster in the background]] The park is best known for its wooden [[roller coaster]], Rutschebanen, or as some people call it, Bjergbanen (''The Mountain Coaster''), built in 1914. It is one of the world's oldest wooden roller coasters that is still operating today. An operator controls the ride by braking down the hills so it won't gain too much speed. It is an [[American Coaster Enthusiasts|ACE]] Coaster Classic.<ref>[http://www.aceonline.org/CoasterAwards/?type=1 ACE Coaster Classic Awards]. Aceonline.org. Retrieved on 15 August 2011.</ref>
Another roller coaster, [[Dæmonen|The Demon]] (''Dæmonen''), features an [[Immelmann loop]], a [[vertical loop]], and a [[zero-G roll]] all during the ride time of just one minute and forty six seconds. An old roller coaster, The Snake (''Slangen''), was removed to have enough space for The Demon. In 2017, Tivoli Gardens added an optional [[virtual reality]] experience to the ride, simulating a flight through ancient China, along with encounters with dragons and demons. The Demon is situated next to the concert hall.
A well-known [[swing ride]], [[Star Flyer (Tivoli Gardens)|The Star Flyer]], opened in Tivoli in 2006. {{convert|80|m|ft|abbr=off}} high and built by the [[Australia]]n company [[Funtime (manufacturer)|Funtime]], it offers panoramic views of the city.<ref name="copenhagenet1"/>
On 1 May 2009, Tivoli Gardens opened the new ride Vertigo, a looping plane ride where the rider pilots the ride, able to control the plane.
A [[Zamperla]] Air Race ride, Aquila, opened on 11 April 2013. It is a giant swing and spinner with centrifugal powers up to 4 g, named after the constellation of the Eagle.<ref>[http://www.tivoli.dk/en/forlystelser/aquila/ Aquila] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140104111553/http://www.tivoli.dk/en/forlystelser/aquila/ |date=4 January 2014 }}. Tivoli.dk. Retrieved 27 December 2013.</ref>
The newest attraction is Fatamorgana, which opened in 2016. This is the world's first [[Condor (ride)|Condor]] 2GH, which offers two separate seating arrangements, one milder version with two-seater gondolas, and a thrilling version in which riders are slung around at high speed while seated in a ring and facing away from the center.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tivoligardens.com/en/forlystelser/fatamorgana|title=Fatamorgana|website=Tivoli|accessdate=2 October 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170619052935/http://www.tivoligardens.com/en/forlystelser/fatamorgana|archivedate=19 June 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

===Other rides=== *'''Aquila''' - giant swing and spinner ride that opened in 2013; with centrifugal powers up to 4 g; height limit 1,2 m. *'''The Bumper Cars''' - classic bumper cars that date from 1926. *'''Fatamorgana''' - a {{convert|43|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall hybrid [[Condor (ride)|Condor]] ride that opened in 2016. Huss. *'''The Ferris Wheel''' (Ballongyngen) - [[Ferris wheel]] which opened during WWII in 1943. *'''The Flying Trunk''' (Den Flyvende Kuffert) - a 7-minute H.C. Andersen-inspired dark ride that opened in 1993 and was renovated in 2010. Mack Rides. *'''The Galley Ships''' - roundabout boats that opened in 1937. *'''The Golden Tower''' - [[turbo drop]] tower that opened in 1999; height {{convert|63|m|ft|abbr=on}}. S&S Worldwide. *'''The Mine''' (Minen) - dark ride in a boat that opened in 2003; this 200 meters long mine-themed ride has a 2 m drop. Mack Rides. *'''The Monsoon''' (Monsunen) - giant swing, a magic carpet ride that opened in 2001; height limit 1,4 m. Zierer. *'''The Star Flyer''' (Himmelskibet) - an {{convert|80|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall sky flyer that opened in 2006; height limit 1,2 m. Funtime. *'''The Swing Carousel''' - swing ride used at Halloween and Christmas. *'''Tik tak'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tivoligardens.com/en/haven+og+forlystelser/forlystelser/tik+tak|title=Tik Tak|website=Tivoli|language=en|access-date=2018-09-19}}</ref> - A spinner ride that opened in the summer 2018; Visitors are 'thrown through time and space', rotated both vertically and horizontally at high speed, while being exposed to forces approaching 4G. [[Mondial (amusement ride manufacturer)|Mondial]] (Shake R5) *'''Vertigo''' - giant swing that opened in 2009; height limit 1,4 m. Technical Park. This looping plane ride reaches a speed of 100 km/h (60 mph) and a height of {{convert|30|m|ft|abbr=off}}.
===Kiddie rides=== *'''The Astronomer''' (Astronomen) - space-themed roundabout boats that opened in 2017. *'''The Big Clock''' (Den blå Safir) - mini Ferris wheel that opened in 1970. *'''The Classic Carousel''' (Dyrekarrusellen) - classic carousel from 1920. *'''The Dragon Boats''' (Dragebådene) - pilot your own boat on the water, opened in 1936. *'''The Elf Train''' - train ride. *'''The Fun House''' - house of fun. *'''The Lighthouse''' - air carousel that opened in 2010. *'''The Little Dragon''' - swing ride. *'''The Little Pilot''' - airplanes that opened in 1990. Remodelled/redesigned into 'The Little Dragon' in 2013 as a part of the reopening of the Merry Corner. *'''The Music Carousel''' - carousel. *'''Minimorgana''' - mini bumper cars that opened in 2016. *'''The Panda''' (Pandaen) - mini drop tower that opened in 2000. Zamperla. *'''The Star Tower''' - Children's 'drop tower' opened in 2013 as a part of the reopening of the Merry Corner. *'''The Temple Tower''' - pull-yourself-up tower ride that opened in 2000. Heege. *'''The Vintage Cars''' - on-track cars that opened in 1959. *'''The Wood Carousel''' - wooden carousel.
===Other attractions=== *'''The Pantomime Theater''' has free pantomime shows. *'''The Tivoli Guard Boys''' stars boys age 9 - 16 who perform music at the park. *'''Tivoli Aquarium''' - located below ground level inside The Concert Hall, entrance is at extra charge. *'''Amusement Arcades''' - extra charge. *'''Tivoli Jackpot''' - cash prizes, extra charge. *'''Tivoli Festival''' - takes place from 14 May to 8 September and features more than 50 different events that include opera shows, symphony concerts, chamber music, pop and rock artists, and much more. On Fridays at 10 pm there is a weekly rock concert under the banner '''Friday Rock'''. *'''[[Tivolis Koncertsal|The Concert Hall]]''' - there has been a concert hall at the park since day one; the current concert hall was built in 1956 and seats 1660 guests. It was renovated in 1985 and the Rotunda was added then. Extra charge music concerts and shows. *'''[[Glass Hall (Tivoli Gardens)|The Glass Hall Theater]]''' - the current Glass Hall was built in 1946, following the destruction of the old one in 1944 during the Nazi occupation of Denmark. the hall features all kinds of music events as well as theater shows for kids. Extra charge. *'''The Harmony Pavilion''' - occasionally music performances throughout the year and special events. *'''Open Air Stage''' - this open-air stage hosts both music performances and other kind of shows. *'''Promenade Pavilion''' - occasionally music performances throughout the year and special events.
In addition, there is a '''Halloween Fest''' in October and '''Christmas Holidays''' in December. During the summer the park has fireworks shows.
===Hotels=== There is one on-site hotel at the park: Hotel Nimb. The Tivoli Hotel & Congress Centre is affiliated with Tivoli Gardens only by name, but close cooperation does take place.
==Performing arts== [[File:Harlekin Columbine Tivoli Denmark.jpg|thumb|Harlekin and Columbine at The Pantomime Theatre]] Besides the rides, Tivoli Gardens also serve as a venue for various performing arts & as an active part of the cultural scene in Copenhagen.
===Tivolis Koncertsal=== {{main|Tivolis Koncertsal}} '''Tivolis Koncertsal''' is a classical concert hall featuring concerts with some of the largest names in international classical music.
===The Pantomime Theatre=== {{main|Pantomimeteatret}} The '''Pantomime Theatre''' is an open-air theatre designed by [[Vilhelm Dahlerup]], also known for the design of the [[Royal Danish Theatre]]. It is a toy-like [[historicism|historicist]] built in Chinese style and noted for its mechanical front curtain that takes five men to operate and unfolds like a [[peafowl|peacock's tail]]. As indicated by the name, it is primarily a scene for pantomime theatre in the classical Italian [[commedia dell'arte]] tradition, which is performed daily with a live [[pit orchestra]]. Besides this original function, the theatre leads a second life as a venue for ballet and [[modern dance]], performing works by choreographers such as [[August Bournonville]], [[Dinna Bjørn]], Louise Midjord and [[Paul James Rooney]].
===The Tivoli Youth Guard=== [[File:Tivoligarden 2011.JPG|250px|thumb|Tivoligarden]] The Tivoli Youth Guard is a formation of boys and girls aged 8–16 dressed in uniforms reminiscent of those of the [[Den Kongelige Livgarde|Royal Danish Guard]] complete with [[bearskin]]s. It was founded in 1844 and gives concerts, makes parades, stands guard at the garden's buildings and monuments at special occasions and represents the gardens at various events. It is composed of a [[Corps of drums]], a military styled [[marching band]] and a [[Guard of honour|honor guard]] platoon.
===Rhythmical music=== During the warmer summer months, Tivoli also features a live music series dubbed ''Fredagsrock'' (''Friday Rock''), which in the past has featured [[Roxette]], the [[Smashing Pumpkins]], [[Sting (musician)|Sting]], [[the Beach Boys]], [[Pet Shop Boys]], [[Kanye West]], [[5 Seconds of Summer]] and popular Danish groups such as [[TV-2 (band)|TV-2]], Nephew, [[Hanne Boel]], [[Raveonettes]] and [[Thomas Helmig]].
During [[Copenhagen Jazz Festival]] Tivoli Gardens is one of the many Copenhagen localities that serves as a venue for concerts.<ref>[http://www.tivoli.dk/composite-7069.htm Tivoli summer 2008] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930062437/http://www.tivoli.dk/composite-7069.htm |date=30 September 2011 }}. Tivoli.dk (29 June 2009). Retrieved on 15 August 2011.</ref>

The '''United States Barista Championship''' or '''USBC''', is a competition to decide the most well rounded [[barista]] in the United States. Competitors prepare and serve three courses of espresso-based beverages consisting of [[espresso]]s, milk beverages, and signature drinks. The Competitor must make all three courses of beverages within a 15 minute time limit and are judged by seven different judges. The judging team consists of 4 sensory judges, 2 technical judges, and 1 head judge. The role of the sensory judge is to score the competitor solely on the quality of the beverage served and customer service. The technical judges are not served drinks, but score the competitor on items ranging from cleanliness to consistency of shot times. Judges undergo a certification process before the competition.
All USBC competitors must first qualify at a CoffeeChamps Qualifying Competition, which is an abbreviated version of the USBC. At the Qualifying Competitions, baristas serve two courses of espresso-based beverages consisting of espressos and signature drinks for 2 scoring sensory judges, 2 non-scoring guest judges or judges-in-training, 2 technical judges, and 1 head judge. There is a 10 minute time limit.
2 Qualifying Competitions are held each year, the top 18 competitors from each Qualifying Competition move on to USBC. Places 7-18 move into Round One of USBC. The top 6 from each Qualifying Competition receive a "buy" into the Semi-Finals round.
USBC consists of 3 rounds: Round One, Semi-Finals, and Finals. At the end of Round One, the competitors with the 6 highest scores will advance to the Semi-Finals round and join the 12 competitors who earned a “buy” from CoffeeChamps. There are 18 competitors in Semi-Finals and 6 competitors in Finals.
The winner represents the United States in the [[World Barista Championship]].
==Past winners== * 2018 Cole McBride * 2017 Kyle Ramage * 2016 Lemuel Butler * 2015 Charles Babinski * 2014 Laila Ghambari * 2013 Pete Licata * 2012 Katie Carguilo * 2011 Pete Licata * 2010 [[Michael Phillips (barista)|Michael Phillips]] * 2009 Michael Phillips * 2008 Kyle Glanville * 2007 Heather Perry * 2006 Matt Riddle * 2005 Phuong Tran * 2004 Bronwen Serna * 2003 Heather Perry
Prior to 2003, the competition was known as the North American Barista Competition. Dismas Smith was the 2002 NABC champion.

In New Zealand, 67% of the population play video games, 48% of video game players are female and the average age of a video game player is 34. New Zealanders spend an average of 88 minutes a day playing video games<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://www.igea.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/Digital-New-Zealand-2016-DNZ16.pdf|title=Digital New Zealand Report 2016|date=2016|publisher=Interactive Games & Entertainment Association}}</ref>
In 2015, domestic video game development in New Zealand supported 568 full-time game developer jobs and collected $78.7 Million in revenue.<ref name=":0" /> Overall, the video game industry in New Zealand is worth $424 million annually, inclusive of traditional retail and digital sales.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://business.scoop.co.nz/2017/03/08/nz-video-games-industry-revenues-race-ahead-to-424m-in-2016/|title=Scoop Business » NZ video games industry revenues race ahead to $424M in 2016|language=en|access-date=2017-06-02}}</ref> Despite the difference in population size, New Zealand game development is comparable to Australia's, in terms of revenue and employment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Senate/Environment_and_Communications/Video_game_industry/Report/c02|title=Chapter 2|last=7111;|first=corporateName=Commonwealth Parliament; address=Parliament House, Canberra, ACT, 2600; contact=+61 2 6277|website=www.aph.gov.au|language=en-AU|access-date=2017-06-02}}</ref>
The industry body for video games in New Zealand is the [[Interactive Games and Entertainment Association]].<ref name=":1" /> The [[New Zealand Game Developers Association]] supports video game development.
==History== New Zealand was an early adopter of the video game phenomenon, despite its remoteness.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://summit.sfu.ca/item/204|title=Early Games Production in New Zealand|author=Melanie Swalwell|publisher=Victoria University of Wellington|date=2005}}</ref> Many Atari 2600 titles were assembled under licence by Monaco Distributors in Auckland.<ref>[http://homepages.ihug.co.nz/~pinwhiz/nz2600.htm Retrogames.co.nz - New Zealand Atari 2600 Games]</ref> New Zealand even developed its own [[Pong]]-style game console, the Sportronic, in the late 1970s, as a result of import licensing laws.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://publicaddress.net/hardnews/sportronic-in-beige/|title=Sportronic in Beige|author=Russell Brown|publisher=Public Address|date=2003-09-22}}</ref><ref>[http://homepages.ihug.co.nz/~pinwhiz/sportn.htm Obscure Pixels - Sportronic]</ref>
''[[Laser Hawk]]'' was developed for the [[Atari 8-bit]] in 1986 by [[Andrew Bradfield]] and Harvey Kong Tin.
''[[Super Skidmarks]]'', released for the [[Commodore Amiga]] in 1995, was developed by Auckland-based Acid Software.
==Major companies and global recognition== Although a minor player in the global video gaming industry, New Zealand has had success with homegrown game developers such as Dinosaur Polo Club (developers of ''[[Mini Metro (video game)|Mini Metro]]'') and [[Sidhe Interactive]].
The action RPG ''[[Path of Exile]]'', developed by [[Grinding Gear Games]] and released in 2013, enjoyed international success.
==Exhibitions== The [[Game Masters (exhibition)|Game Masters]] exhibition was held at the [[Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa]], from 15 December 2012 through to 28 April 2013.
==Controversies== In 2003, ''[[Manhunt (video game)|Manhunt]]'' became the first video game officially banned in New Zealand.<ref>{{cite news|title=New Zealand bans video game|work=[[MSNBC]]|date=|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/3693947/ns/technology_and_science-games/t/new-zealand-bans-video-game/|accessdate=2011-05-23|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105084639/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/3693947/ns/technology_and_science-games/t/new-zealand-bans-video-game/|archive-date=2012-11-05|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>

[[Image:Stern-kabarett-Mainz.jpg|thumb|Star of Satire in Mainz]] [[Image:Sterne der satire-mz.jpg|thumb|"Star of Satire - Walk of Fame of Cabaret - since 2004"]]
The '''Walk of Fame of Cabaret''' is a [[sidewalk]] between [[Proviant-Magazin]] and [[Schönborner Hof]] in [[Mainz]], [[Germany]], which is embedded with more than 40 seven-pointed irregularly shaped stars featuring the names of [[cabaret]] [[celebrity|celebrities]] selected by a group of experts and honored by several sponsors for their contributions to the cabaret culture.
The first stars, awarded on July 16, 2004, were inaugurated in the presence of [[Christina Weiss]], Culture Representative and [[Minister of State]] of Germany and [[Kurt Beck]], the premier of the German federal state of [[Rhineland-Palatinate]]. In January 2007, [[Peter Hammerschlag]] was honored, and his became the 43rd star on the walk.
== Characteristics == The Walk of Fame runs north to south between Münsterstraße and Schillerstraße.
Each star consists of a stainless-steel seven-pointed irregularly shaped star, inlaid into a bronze square. Inside the star, the signature of the honoree is etched. The full name of the honoree in [[capital letters]] can be seen on the bronze square, as well as the sponsor in normal letters.
The committee of experts initially selected 80 deceased stars to be honored on the walk of fame. Additionally to these, each year a living author or interpreter receives a star.
== Details on the honorees == Details on the honorees may be found at the nearby Stiftung Deutsches Kabarett (German Cabaret Foundation). Here, the core of the German Cabaret Archive is formed by more than eighty [[literary estate]]s with biographies, documents and cultural heritage, regarding eighty thousand people from the history of cabaret and the forms of comedy that preceded it. This archive is based on the private initiative of Reinhard Hippen (1961). The counterpart of the "Walk of Fame" can be found in the "[[Hall of Fame]]" in the [[Bernburg]] castle, in [[Saxony-Anhalt]]. Numerous exhibits remind viewers of the "immortals" of cabaret.

{{advert|date=May 2018}} [[File:We Said Go Travel.jpg|thumb|We Said Go Travel banner from We Said Go Travel website by [[Lisa Ellen Niver]]]]'''We Said Go Travel''' is a global community of over sixteen hundred writers from seventy five countries with articles from every continent. Stories are shared with photos and video from a perspective of the transformative power of travel. We Said Go Travel has hosted live and online events as well as travel writing contests.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.johnnyjet.com/2013/01/travel-contests-week-of-january-9th-2012/ |title = Travel Contest Round-up January 2013 |work =Johnny Jet }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.johnnyjet.com/2013/05/travel-contests-week-of-may-15th-2013/ |title = Travel Contest Round-up May 2013 |work =Johnny Jet}}</ref>
==History== The original blog began on blogspot by [[Lisa Ellen Niver]], a member of the [[Travelers' Century Club]]. The We Said Go Travel<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.wesaidgotravel.com/ |title = We Said Go Travel Website}}</ref> website with earned ratings of PR 5 and PA 50 began in May 2010. The first content was the newsletters previously published online during an eleven-month sabbatical in [[South-east Asia]] from August 2008-July 2009.
The site was created as a platform for a travel memoir<ref>{{cite web |url =http://www.wesaidgotravel.com/our-book|title =Rajna Travel memoir}}</ref> about a sabbatical year which included an underwater engagement, losing sixty pounds and visiting twelve countries.
With the first event in March 2011,<ref>{{cite web |url =http://www.westsidetoday.com/n4382/we-said-go-travel.html |title =Uncovering Jewish Morocco, March 24, 2011: Speaker: Lisa Ellen Niver |work =Westside Today}}</ref> a larger platform was required and a website was built on weebly.com at www.wesaidgotravel.com with the blog being on www.wesaidgotravel.net. As the number of followers and events grew, it was necessary to combine the two sites into one on wordpress on www.wesaidgotravel.com.
In April 2011, Niver was invited to have a "We Said Go Travel" Blog on the ''[[The Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles|Jewish Journal]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.jewishjournal.com/wesaidgotravel |title = Jewish Journal Column}}</ref>
At the fourth We Said Go Travel event in October 2011,<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.wesaidgotravel.com/los-angeles-certificate-of-appreciation|title = Award from Los Angeles City Council Member Bill Rosendahl}}</ref> [[Bill Rosendahl]] gave an award in honor of the contributions to the city for leadership and community building efforts of the founders and the site.
Various social media sites, including [[Facebook]], [[Twitter]], [[LinkedIn]], [[Pinterest]], and [[Google+]], were added for promotion and to increase traffic and views. In April 2011, a [[YouTube]] channel was added and as of July 2013 it has 130 videos and over 110,000 views. As of March 2015, there are over 340 videos and over 300,000 views. Instagram has also been added.<ref>https://instagram.com/wesaidgotravel/</ref>
Highlights of recent articles: "A Royal Cremation in Ubud" in National Geographic Intelligent Traveler,<ref>{{cite web |url = http://intelligenttravel.nationalgeographic.com/2012/11/22/a-royal-cremation-in-ubud/ |title = A Royal Cremation in Ubud |work = National Geographic Intelligent Traveler}}</ref> and in print about the festival at [[Inle Lake]] in the ''[[Myanmar Times]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://mmtimes.com/index.php/lifestyle/3170-at-inle-the-best-seats-in-the-house.html |title = Inle Lake: The Best Seats in the House |work = in print Myanmar Times}}</ref>
In January 2013, Kred recognized the site with a Top 5% Elite Influencer in Travel Badge.<ref>[by email from Andrew Grill, Kred.com CEO]</ref> The founders were invited to speak in [[Kathmandu]] in April 2013 by the Nepal Tourism Board, where they read from their travel memoir for the first time. The feature editor interviewed them and had a full-page article was published in the ''[[Himalayan Times]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://thehimalayantimes.com/fullNews.php?headline=Travelling+...&NewsID=373383 |title = Travelling and Falling in Love |work = in print Himalayan Times}}</ref>
In March 2013, The Nomadic Family awarded We Said Go Travel as #5 of the Top 50 Best Travel Blogs of 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url =http://thenomadicfamily.com/2013/03/2012-best-travel-blogs-the-50-coolest-most-inspirational-out-there/|title = We Said Go Travel #5 in Top 50 Best Travel Blogs of 2012 |work =The Nomadic Family}}</ref> In May 2013, Kred recognized the site with a Top 1% Elite Influencer in Travel Badge.<ref>[by email from Andrew Grill, Kred.com CEO]</ref>
In August 2013, We Said Go Travel was added to the ninth edition of [[Nomadic Samuel]]'s Top 100 Travel Blogs at #97. .<ref>{{cite web |url =http://nomadicsamuel.com/top100travelblogs/top-100-travel-blogs-seomoz-alexa-rankings-volume-ix-september-2013|title = We Said Go Travel in Top 100 Travel Blogs |work =Nomadic Samuel}}</ref> In December 2013, the site moved to #79 on the list.<ref>{{cite web |url =http://nomadicsamuel.com/top100travelblogs|title = We Said Go Travel in Top 100 Travel Blogs |work =Nomadic Samuel}}</ref>
Both are bloggers for ''[[Huffington Post]]''<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/lisa-niver-rajna/ |title = Huffington Post column}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/lisa-niver-rajna/myanmar-visa-travel_b_2328132.html |title = A Visa Scavenger Hunt to Visit Myanmar |work = Huffington Post Travel}}</ref> as well as the ''Jewish Journal''.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.jewishjournal.com/wesaidgotravel |title = Jewish Journal Column}}</ref> Their first ''Huffington Post'' articles were a "He Said, She Said" on their travels in [[Bagan]], [[Myanmar]]. George's article: "One Thing My Wife and I Don't Agree on" <ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/george-rajna/travel-abroad-the-one-thing-my-wife-and-i-dont-agree-on_b_2264626.html |title = One Thing My Wife and I Don't Agree on |work = Huffington Post}}</ref> Lisa's article: "Terrorized by My Bike For My Birthday in Bagan" <ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/lisa-niver-rajna/bike-adventure_b_2096615.html |title = Terrorized by My Bike For My Birthday in Bagan |work = Huffington Post}}</ref>
In July 2013, We Said Go Travel became the publisher for the memoir, [[Traveling in Sin]], by Lisa Ellen Niver and George Rajna about their first year sabbatical in Asia.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.jewishjournal.com/wesaidgotravel/item/traveling_in_sin |title = Traveling in Sin |work = Jewish Journal}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.westsidetoday.com/n9750/traveling-around-the-world.html |title =Traveling Around the World in Sin |work =Westside Today}}</ref>
In January 2015, the seventh We Said Go Travel writing contest was held. There have been three contests a year since January 2013: Inspiration, Independence and Gratitude.<ref>http://www.wesaidgotravel.com/writing-contest/</ref>
